characters: MIRANDA'S RESIGNED DAILY GRIND IN QUICK DISSOLVES --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PUSH in on a sleeping couple in the dark. The ALARM CLOCK reads 5:59 AM. The woman's eyes open a second before the alarm beeps and turns it off. She grabs a glass of water on her bedside table and drinks it. Climbs out of bed past typical bedside photographs (wedding, vacation, etc.). This is MIRANDA GREY: 30, sharp and prettier than she knows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miranda slides through the water. Swimming cap on, goggles. Her STEADY BREATHING takes us in and out of the water. Something unsettling about this sound. Something slightly unsettling too about her detached manner. A person on autopilot, recognizing only the water and the perfectly aligned lap stripes leading her path. Like graphic metaphors for her own conscience: flat. She emerges from the pool and self-consciously wraps herself in a towel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miranda pays for a pair of coffees and a newspaper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miranda's husband DOUGLAS GREY (older, a superficial analysis would suggest a father figure) serves breakfast. Miranda smiles thank you and goes back to studying a case file. He sips from his takeout coffee and reads the newspaper. A pleasant domestic scene. It's 8:00 AM.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miranda's Volvo pulls in as students amble up the steps. Doug kisses his wife and hops out. Exemplary carpoolers. Students are already chatting him up as Miranda drives off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miranda's car at some sort of guard gate. A BUZZER lets her in. As the car drives past we read the plate on the wall:

dialogues.speaker: "WOODWARD FORENSIC INSTITUTE"
dialogues.text: The gate shuts behind her with a certain finality as we...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stark walls. Simple decor. Bookshelves packed with the according psychiatric tomes and diplomas. Miranda faces a troubled young mess of a woman, CHLOE: charismatic, deranged and forever trying to provoke. Mid-session:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is your stepfather who came to visit you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My stepfather?  No.   He's dead. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I killed him. Miranda tries not to act surprised at this breakthrough. Responds with the even keel of a trained psychiatrist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the first time you admit it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So? There's a first time for everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (jotting this down)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It means you're finally past the denial stage. This is good, Chloe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never killed anyone who didn't deserve it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You only killed your stepfather as far as I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I should've taken care of my mother. She knew all along.    You remind me of her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I remind you of your mother?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Always so put together. Like you iron your underwear. Like your pussy is the apricot of the Promised Land and the bread of the --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (getting her back on track)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's get back to your visitor last night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Devil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright, the Devil. Why would the Devil visit you? It's already hell in here, what would he have to gain?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He came to fuck an angel. (giggles at that)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm his dirty angel. Before Miranda can analyze that one, the room LIGHTS FLIC AND DIE. Darkness. Miranda's breathing speeds up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He grabbed me by the hair while I sucked him and usually I love that, I just do -- maybe you can tell me why I love it so much -- but not this time, he was just too rough -- As suddenly as it went out, now the POWER RETURNS.      A visibly uncomfortable Miranda checks the clock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's it until Monday. Try and get some sleep tonight, okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, Doctor. (leans in)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crazy people hear messages from God. Not the Devil. You know that, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't say you were crazy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't have to say it. She almost doesn't seem crazy when she says this. Almost. TWO ORDERLIES appear at the door. Miranda nods for them to escort Chloe. Chloe shakes their hands away from her, strides off dramatically. The princess of the asylum.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miranda locks her office, armed with paperwork. The end of another workweek. DR. PETE GRAHAM, a good ten years older and Miranda's best friend on the job, approaches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Grey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Graham. They walk along with the easy confidence of colleagues who not only respect each other, but enjoy each other. lot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Power went out again in our wing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (knows what's coming)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Same here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not shrink-appropriate to be afraid of the dark, you know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not shrink appropriate and you're about to get promoted. Everybody's afraid of something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What am I afraid of?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yourself. At least you should be. What are you up to this weekend?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Write a little country music, decline invites to grand social events, drink myself to sleep -- the usual. You?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doug wants to look at some Real Estate up at Willow's Creek.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He thinks it's fun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So is golfing, I'm told.   Who was your six o'clock?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chloe McGrath -- talk about trying to empty the ocean with a tea cup. She's a mess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hear Manhattan's full of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't start with that. I already turned down the job. We're staying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good girl. They have reached an office marked "DR. PHILLIP PARSONS DIRECTOR" and peer in to see Parsons (50's, distinguished, commands respect from everyone) on the phone. He gestures for Pete to sit. Miranda is about to exit when he covers the mouthpiece --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miranda, my wife keeps wanting to set that dinner with you and Doug. Are you free tonight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's stuck at a school board meeting. Parsons looks through his appointment book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've been here a year already, Dorothy's starting to take this personal. How's next Wednesday?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Next Wednesday it is, Phil. He nods at her with a smile and returns to his phone call.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miranda drives off, leaving the majestic grounds behind. A GUARD waves her off. END OPENING CREDITS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miranda slows down at the sight of colored lights up ahead. A knocked-down telephone post blocks the road. EMERGENCY VEHICLES at the scene. A patrolman waves her down.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: SHERIFF RYAN, 40'S, recognizes her and ambles over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anybody hurt, Sheriff?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nah, telephone post just decided to fall. It'll take us a while to clear this up so I'm afraid you're gonna have to take the long way home, Miranda.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you say so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And tell your husband he owes me a phone call.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will do. Wouldn't want him in trouble with the authorities.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That a girl. The law never sleeps and all that. You take care now. He taps on her hood and heads back to the site.      She shifts into reverse and makes a U-turn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miranda drives down the curvy road toward an old bridge. Something definitely creepy about this deserted place --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miranda dials a number on her cell phone, gets the machine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, it's me. Are you there? Pick up, pick up. I'm on my way but I just got detoured so I'm... A bump on the road makes her drop the phone on the passenger seat. She reaches for it and when she looks up we see:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A TEENAGE GIRL stands smack in front of us.      Naked. About to get pummelled by us.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: Miranda swerves to avoid her and slams into the railing. METAL SCREECHES as she struggles to regain control of the car and finally BRAKES TO A HALT -- She looks in her rearview mirror: the girl is standing back there. Drunk or high or in any case completely out of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stay on the line. Don't go anywhere. The weirdest thing just -- (the phone cuts out)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello? Hello?

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She stares at the dead phone.      Punches the buttons on No go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wonderful. She tosses the phone on the seat and hops out of the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miranda cautiously approaches the girl, who is now not moving. Just standing there. Her back to us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello?   Are you hurt?   Hello? Nothing.     As we get closer we see she is covered in bruises.     Clearly something horrible has happened to h

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Were you in an accident? Were you attacked? It's okay, I'm a doctor. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My name is Miranda Grey... And now she turns. Young, seventeen tops. Busted lip, black eye. Miranda pulls off her coat, wraps it around the girl --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're in shock right now, that's perfectly natural. I'm going to get you to the hospital. Okay? The girl suddenly grips Miranda's arm.         Hard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be scared. It's going to be fine. Now the girl is touching Miranda's face. Her movements desperate, smothering. Like the movements of a drowning person. Miranda tries to push the girl's hands back down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hands off me, okay? Tell me your name, do you remember your name? The girl tries to speak but no words come out. Instead she produces a strained, wettish sound. Creepy as hell. And now she is prying Miranda's mouth open and she's much stronger than expected and Miranda is panicking --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing? I'm trying to help you --?! The girl opens her own mouth wide like a snake. And as Miranda muffles a scream, blood starts leaking out of the girl's eye sockets and from wounds all over her body.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miranda wakes up in a cold sweat.         Just a bad drea beat. FAINT at first but GROWING LOUDER, we hear a REPETITIVE SOUND outside. Like an ECHO of some sort, but vaguely familiar: THWIP, THWIP, THWIP. Miranda takes a deep breath, reaches for the glass of water on her bedside table. Except... it's not there. She turns to her husband but he's not in the bed. And now she glances around the room and realizes this is not her bedroom. She climbs off the bed and walks in the dark. Trips over something. A TRAY that CLANGS LOUDLY. Her heartbeat goes haywire. She feels her way along the wall to a small opening in the door. A glass pane. She peers through the glass at the empty corridor outside, realizing what this must mean, realizing she's inside a cell. She jiggles the handle and pounds on the door, frantic --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello?   Somebody help me!

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: CAMERA SOARS through the tall iron gates, past the guard. Now we spot the source of our continuing THWIP THWIP sound: sprinklers watering the impressively-kept gardens. The expansive complex is more Victorian campus than drab prison, with separate wings (male and female), research units, libraries, gym and volunteer outpatient center.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bored group of female patients listen to a social worker lecturing them. A janitor mops a long corridor. Patients study at the library under the watchful eye of orderlies. A doctor and two orderlies hold down a patient having an epileptic fit (we'll soon know her as SHELLEY). They force a biting block in her mouth to avoid her swallowing her tongue, prepare a syringe. Institute director Phil Parsons at a meeting with other doctors, discussing a patient's progress on a chart. Now we are MOVING up the main building's wall and THROUGH large windows into --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete rushes up two steps at a time, passing by a NURSE WITH A CART OF MEDS, who nods respectfully as he goes --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An ORDERLY unlocks the door for Pete. Through the glass pane he can see a visibly upset Miranda arguing with the head nurse: a tough as nails woman in her 50's: IRENE. ORDERLY #1

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sleeping beauty is awake. Peter forces a smile, enters --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MIRANDA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter, what the hell is going on? Pete nods at Irene: it's okay, he'll take it from here. PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you feel? MIRANDA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you think I feel?    Is this a joke? Peter is half-listening to her, half-signaling to the nurse with the meds to come in. Miranda catches all of this, growing more agitated. She wears the uniform all patients wear: a white T-shirt and sweats. Her wedding ring is gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Giving you something to calm down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't need to calm down.   What I need is an explanation Pete grabs the meds from the nurse. Irene and the attendant step closer to help. Miranda feels them closing in on her. Peter's tone is infuriatingly gentle:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just take this and we can sit down and chat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why here, why not in my office? She looks at the silent faces around her. No sympathy. Or maybe too much sympathy. Either way it's unnerving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want an anticonvulsant, at least give me Valium.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nods at nurse)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fifty milligrams.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ, you're gonna knock me out? Ten milligrams.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (final offer)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twenty. The nurse complies. Miranda stares at the meds, trying desperately to put this into some kind of perspective.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How would you feel if you woke up in a goddamn cell, dressed like this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can discuss it at length after you take your meds. Awkward nods from Irene, the nurse and the attendant. Pete holds Miranda's gaze. Miranda takes her meds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.    This better be good. Pete motions for the others to leave them alone. one they file out and lock the door behind them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miranda paces.       Alone with Pete, she is even more up

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miranda, this is very awkward. Technically I shouldn't even be treating you but the court has granted us a waiver until you're transferred. So whatever is said here won't leave this room. I won't tell Parsons, I won't tell anyone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to talk to my husband.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't to that. Sit down, please. Try to relax.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why would I pretend to be in any way relaxed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I understand you're upset. But we need to put some things in order.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two massive understatements. He hesitates, unsure where to begin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long have you been here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is this? Why are you doing this to me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just answer the question.    Humor me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, my name is Miranda Grey. I'm a psychiatrist. I transferred here to the Woodward Forensic Institute a little over a year ago. My job entails dealing with a ward of schizophrenic women between the ages of eighteen and fifty-fife --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't mean how long you've worked here, I mean how long you've been staying here. This stops her. Wanting desperately to whip out a comeback but realizing she doesn't know the answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a doctor, yes? Or was medical school just an elaborate dream?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course you're a doctor. A great doctor in fact. The hint of sadness in his voice alarms her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete, how long have I been here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (barely audible)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were admitted to the neurosurgical unit seizing violently. That lasted three days. Scans revealed left-sided weakness, numbness and severe fontal lobe deficits. Miranda shakes her head in disbelief, but we --

dialogues.speaker: FLASHBACK
dialogues.text: Miranda seizing violently FROM HER POV: Doctors struggling to contain her. Arms thrashing, legs. FLASHES of the wall, the floor. Head crashing against a cart, out of control.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You came out of it and tested negative for PCP, underwent extensive hypnosis and received amytal injections. FLASH: Miranda being tied down.      A nurse with a syringe --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks down at her wrists with the reddish marks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were tied down for a day and a half so you wouldn't hurt yourself and then you went into a state of, well -- (how to put this?)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've been pretty much catatonic. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the first time you speak. Miranda, speechless.     Reality sinking in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doug must be worried sick.   I need to call him -- Pete shakes his head emphatically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're the most logical person I know, bar none. Plus you have a photographic memory -- unconfirmed, but you do remember events and phrases more accurately than anyone around. Why am I telling you this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're establishing my personality as fairly intellectual, you don't consider me impulsive or emotional.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And that's a fair assessment, no?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, that's fair. And following this pattern of analysis, we're about to discuss a traumatic event that rendered this psychological profile useless, correct?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two hundred percent. A pause here. He's waiting for her to continue. She's not used to being on the other side of the therapist's table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think I'm in denial. That I'm putting on a brave show -- that this is a 'cover' for some unbearable emotion I'm hiding. Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't analyze yourself, just focus on remembering.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I remember Friday night after work, if you say that was five days ago -- (pushing on)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyway, I asked you what you were doing for the weekend and you said the usual and you made a joke about writing country songs and drinking yourself to sleep and I told you I was going to look at some real estate in Willows Creek with Doug.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And then what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then I drove home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And then what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got home, I guess, and had dinner by myself because -- (pauses, struggling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because Doug had an alumni meeting at his school and he was going to get a ride back. He's the principal now, as you well know. She stops here. Pete waits. The silence is deafening. She pushes on, but her hands shake a little.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But wait -- there was an accident before that, wasn't there? A girl -- she had been beaten. I took her to the hospital, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There was indeed an accident, you were detoured by the cops. But there's no report of any girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, the cops weren't there. They were back on Main Road. A knocked-down telephone post, correct? Pete nods.     Miranda is all foggy on the details:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I saw the girl after that.   She was bleeding.

dialogues.speaker: FLASHBACK
dialogues.text: sway in the night breeze with their gentle tinkling SOUND, more menacing than joyful --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A breathless Miranda wipes her face, leaving a thick streak of blood on it.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA'S EYE
dialogues.text: Jittery, alert. We scour her every blood vessel, iris, pupil. FILLING the SCREEN and now we distinctly make out an eerie shape reflected inside of it. But just for a sec -- The teenage girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about your husband, what can you tell me about him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miranda shakes the puzzling images out of her head:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me? PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the last memory you have of him that night? MIRANDA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My last -- ? (frowns)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me nothing happened to Doug. PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's backtrack a second. You left your office, you were driving home, you got detoured by the police -- Did you call someone on the phone that night?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.    I might have. PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who would you call? MIRANDA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I might have called Doug to tell him something. Or checked my answering service. PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Were you seeing someone else that night? MIRANDA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I beg your pardon? PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There was some trouble in your marriage, wasn't there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course not. She shakes her head emphatically as we:

dialogues.speaker: FLASHBACK
dialogues.text: CAMERA PANS ACROSS the large space to find Miranda and a MAN (whose face we don't see) kissing heatedly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wasn't there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miranda chases the disconcerting image out of her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. There was no trouble in my marriage, I don't know what -- (stops herself)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is no trouble in my marriage. You just used the past tense; why? His face says he doesn't know how to tell her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did something happen to Doug?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't remember anything else. Anything at all? Frustrated, she snatches his cell phone and starts to dial:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is preposterous.    What's wrong with Doug?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's dead. This stops her cold. Time stands eerily still. She stares at Pete as if by looking at him long enough, he will contradict his statement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, he's not. Don't tell me that. Don't tell me that. (sickened)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you -- sure?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm positive. (painful beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You killed him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Irene and TWO NURSE rush to Miranda's cell.      WE HEAR hysterical CRIES from inside --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete struggles to contain Miranda, who howls disparagingly. PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's going to be alright, Miranda. You just need to sleep. It's going to be alright -- Off Pete's nod, a nurse injects the syringe into Miranda's arm. They hold her down with great effort as she continues to cry, and we...

dialogues.speaker: FLASHBACK SEQUENCE
dialogues.text: A blur of images and scrambled snippets of memories come at us rapid-fire, like a drug-induced dream:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miranda's CAR SCREECHES to a stop and she jumps out, glances around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Graduation night. School principal Douglas Grey shakes hands with proud parents and clumsily formal students. Miranda grabs a drink from a nearby tray, bored. DOUG (re: her drink)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that number three? MIRANDA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Mr. Principal. Special occasion -- I'm celebrating how proud I am of my husband tonight. He smiles weakly at the compliment. Moves his hand towards her, in an affectionate gesture (or so Miranda thinks) but instead fixes her bra strap. Ever methodical.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miranda and a man exit the theater.    Giggling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doug laying on the floor covered with bloodstains. Bloodstained axe on floor in f.g. Walls covered with bloodstains.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A flustered Miranda fumbles with her purse and keys, heads for the door. She tries to fix her smeared lipstick and messed-up hair. TURNS TO CAMERA: MIRANDA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. The fact is I'm married and I -- this is not me, this is a mistake. First we hear our mystery man's voice, then we see him: Pete. (Yes, the same person she kissed and went to the movies with.) He places his hand on the door, blocking her. PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your marriage is the mistake and you know it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't. PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. That was out of line. I feel like a school kid hiding from the Principal. MIRANDA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are hiding from the Principal. He smiles. Touches her face tenderly. Torn. A person used to doing the right thing but not liking that at the moment. PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I would just like to spend some time together. MIRANDA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We spend time together every day. PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I meant minus the schizophrenic women.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to go.    I need time to think.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He nods.     Opens the door for her.     She starts to wa away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be too hard on yourself, Dr. Grey. You haven't done anything wrong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not yet.   But I want to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PUSH INTO a quiet house on a quiet suburban street. Two Volvos parked in the driveway. Perfectly-kept front lawn.

dialogues.speaker: FLASHBACK
dialogues.text: Another near-subliminal glimpse of Doug laying on the floor covered with bloodstains. Bloodstained axe on floor in f.g. Walls covered with bloodstains.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miranda and Doug laugh at their wedding. It's clearly hot, because she wipes sweat off his brow with a handkerchief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A breathless Miranda wipes her face, leaving a thick streak of blood on it. She looks down at her hand, noticing the blood -- and now we are back in --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miranda wakes up with a start. The darkness renders the room almost void of any color. Monochromatic. It takes her a moment to orient herself. Her eyes wander across the unfamiliar room, feeling like she's being watched. We become aware of a RAGGED BREATHING sound. Like somebody is standing over her bed. But we don't see anything. Miranda gingerly crosses to the door and peeks through the glass partition into the empty corridor. She glances back at the room, stills seeing nothing -- and bangs on the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I get some assistance here? Hello?! She waits.     Bangs on the door again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Irene?!   Anybody!? A beat. And now finally we hear FOOTSTEPS APPROACHING. A light is switched on down the corridor. The FOOTSTEPS get CLOSER... and CLOSER... Miranda tries to appear composed. Wipes sweat off her forehead. Fixes her hair. The FOOTSTEPS now STOP right out side the door. A KEY goes into the lock and JIGGLES it. Miranda waits for the door to open but nothing happens. Confused, she steps up to the glass partition and peeks -- The second her face touches the glass, she is met by a pair of piercing eyes. The eerie teenage girl. Miranda jumps back, screams. And when she looks up again, the image is gone.      A be Rational thought kicking in --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to self)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wake up, wake up... (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're dreaming. It's not real. An anxiety dream, that's all. That's all. This is dream logic. If it was real, they would have heard you scream. There are twenty employees on the night shift. Fact. At least twenty. She props herself with her back against the wall. With a view of the whole cell. Just in case. Staring at the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm just dreaming. And now, FAINTLY at first, but GROWING LOUDER -- FOOTSTEPS can be heard APPROACHING outside. Just like before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm dreaming, I'm dreaming, I'm dreaming, I'm dreaming. Like her life depends on that mantra. The FOOTSTEPS get CLOSER. And her voice begins to falter --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (voice rising)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm dreaming, I'm dreaming -- And now the FOOTSTEPS pause outside her door like before and she holds her breath, horrified, when suddenly we are hit with the sudden glare of returning light. EVERYTHING FLASHES WHITE and then COLOR RETURNS --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rise and shine, ladies!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Irene tries to shake Miranda awake.       An orderly and stand by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shaking her)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That means you, honey.   Up -- ! No reaction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rise and shine now.    Wake up. She shakes her harder. And now Miranda's EYES SHOOT OPEN and she grips Irene's arm. Hard. Like the teenage girl did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Easy now, it's okay. Miranda stares at her, coming back to. Starts to speak but has no voice. Clears her throat --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need to see Peter Graham.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you have a session scheduled this afternoon --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's not even in yet, now let go my arm, honey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doctor Grey, if you don't mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Actually I do mind. I start calling you 'doctor' and everybody else wants to be called 'doctor' --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please. It's a bit different, wouldn't you say -- ? Irene reaches out her hand and the nurse places a cup with meds on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you think you're doing?    I want to speak to my lawyer -- wait, what are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My job. Irene shoves the meds into Miranda's mouth --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon, Irene, don't do this. I'm calm now, look -- I'm calm -- ! She struggles as they hold her down and Irene sedates her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DRIFTING PAST the female patients at their usual activiti Some watch TV, play dominoes, some pretend to read, some stare out blankly. Here's Chloe at a table, engaged in some sort of trivia game with a tattooed Southern redhead named JENNA:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mallorol, Matzine, Megaphen, Meallaril-S, Meleretten, Meleril, Mellaril, Mellaril-S, Mesoridazine, Methotrimaprazine, Mixidol, Moban Modalina --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Modalina?   Isn't that a band?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trade name for Triflupoerazine. Look it up. Chloe shrugs, if you say so.       Jenna resumes:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moditen, Molindone, Moltipress, Motival. That's it for the 'M's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not bad. High potency neuroleptics starting with 'J.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trick question. There's only Jatroneural.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you wanna bet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bet you a soda. Chloe checks a reference book.       Nods, impressed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right on the money, cowgirl. Twenty points and a soda. CAMERA FOLLOWS HER INTENT GAZE to another patient, SHELLEY (the same patient we saw earlier mid-fit) moseying across the room. Nervously takes a seat beside Miranda.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi there, Doc. It takes a moment for the heavily-drugged Miranda to react. She looks up slowly: eyes glazed, painfully out of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never got shrinked by you but all I hear is nothing gets past you, I mean, that's just hearsay and I don't pay much attention to hearsay because now they say you hacked your husband with an axe but I say maybe it just slipped, right?

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Miranda notices Shelley is toying with a wrinkled NEWSPAPER CLIPPING. Shelley catches this look and slides it over to her. Without malice, like a child.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They put your picture in the paper. It reads "SCHOOL PRINCIPAL SLAUGHTERED. WIFE UNDER ARREST." Photos of Miranda, Douglas, their house. Miranda stares at it in disbelief.      Growing sick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How did you get this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chloe did. Who knows how? Not me. Around here I'm on a need to know basis about stuff and most stuff I don't need to know. My point is about people talking behind other people's backs. Like before I was here, everything I did I thought, 'this'll get them,' wanting their approval, wanting them to say good things behind my back. But now I'm more anonymous, more myself. I'm Shelley. Miranda slides the clipping back to Shelley, clueless as to how to get out of this conversation, but Shelley has no problem holding a conversation all by herself --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not like, undercover here, are you? They pulled that at Spring Grove, had a bunch of doctors pretend they were patients, see if they could handle it. Most quit after day one. You're not, are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Shelley.   I'm not undercover.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because if you were, I'm like the Fort Knox of secrets. Ask anybody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's good to know. But I'm not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say no more. (sotto)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I understand perfectly. She hands Miranda paper and some crayons, whispers:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drawing is a great cover.   Good luck to you. With a wink, she's gone. Miranda looks at the room around her: Chloe spying on her in the corner, Irene and the nurse sharing a laugh, other patients ambling about, arguing -- Life among the insane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patients undress in the bare-bones locker area. An uneasy Miranda is handed a bar of soap and towel by Irene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't -- I think I'm alright.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You go in last because you're special. (off Miranda's look)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not a Mexican prison, toots. Everybody here minds their own business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If it's all the same, I'd rather --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: State law says we keep you ladies clean. And I'm a stickler for the law. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now come on. If you go downtown, you gotta dance. Miranda studies the patients already under the spray of the shower. Something vaguely concentration camp-like about institutional bathing.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The shower, like everything else in this place, is regulated by shifts, so that various groupings of patients each get their turn. Miranda feels Chloe's gaze on her across the room. She is stripping off her clothes for Miranda's benefit, gleefully mangling the last refrain from the Stones' "START ME UP."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (checking watch)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's five minutes, group one. (to Chloe's group)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright, ladies, nice and easy. The first group of bathers file out, dripping wet past Miranda, in all shapes and sizes. She registers their many scars and tattoos, like maps of troubled souls: names of men, places, religious quotes. Burn scars, cuts, needle marks. They begin to towel off as Miranda, slowly and painfully self-conscious, begins to undress in the corner. A moment later Irene nods for her to go in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miranda hangs her head under the spray and closes her eyes, trying to shut it all out. The SOUNDS slowly FADE OUT until all we have is Miranda and her RAGGED BREATHING. Chloe and Shelley, the last two out from the previous group, grab towels. Chloe winks at Miranda when she catches her staring, but Miranda is not staring at her. She is staring past her at the tile wall. More specifically at a hole in the tile where a busted water pipe pokes out. Clearly at some point there was a handle there, but now it is just a hole with a busted pipe. PUSH INTO the hole to see a perfectly-formed globule of blood emerge, following by a GURGLING sound which seems to come from deep in the bowels of the plumbing system. The blood lingers tentatively, as if unfamiliar with the laws of gravity, before tracing an upward line along the tile. The GURGLING GROWS LOUDER, CLOSER, and now more blood flows from the hole and spreads up the wall. Miranda looks away, disturbed, and now realizes she is the only one left in the showers. Panic. Shuts her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to self)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It isn't real. It isn't real. Opens her eyes. Five letters are written in blood.       N-O-T-A-L. Shaking, nauseous, she looks down at her feet and the drain, too scared to look back up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to self)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It isn't real. You're hallucinating. Perhaps. But now blood drips by       her ankle, DRIP, DR DRIP. And the shooting pain she       feels is coming fro arm. What the hell -- ? WE SEE        SHARP SLASHES appea on her skin, like some invisible      knife is slicing he Hallucination or not, she bolts out of the showers --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miranda wraps a towel around her bloody arm, too freaked out to process anything. Fumbles for her clothes and head straight to Shelley, tying her shoelaces, muttering.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shelley?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And pick up those damn cigarette butts. Jesus, TV is dumb --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shelley, can you do me a favor?? Shelley fixes her with an intense conspiratorial look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The housewives will find something better to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you go in the shower and tell me if you see anything on the wall? Shelley doesn't respond. Simply crosses over and heads for the showers. Miranda gets dressed when a hand on her shoulder makes her jump --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enough privacy for you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.   Thank you, Irene. But now Irene notices the blood seeping through the towel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did you do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing.   It's nothing --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell did you do to yourself?! And now the other patients are curiously watching as orderlies RUSH IN to haul her away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THROUGH a glass pane we see a NURSE bandaging Miranda's arm. Parsons and Irene confer just outside the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I looked away for a second. It's unacceptable, won't happen again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not your fault. Patients always find a way to hurt themselves if that's what they want.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just didn't peg her for a cutter, that's all. Parsons watches Miranda through the glass.       She can' look him in the eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miranda (with her fresh new bandage) ignores the looks from the other patients as she rejoins them. Spots Shelley by the window furthest from the wardens. Scared.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my God.   Oh my God.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You saw it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, Doctor. Some people, they have a gift. And in here, because they categorize us as a bunch of schizos, they refuse to acknowledge that. It's like that Hubble telescope that sees things a trillion miles away but what it's seeing is just reflected light of a star that died a thousand years ago? It's like that. Doesn't mean you're crazy. It only means your eyes open in a different way. Miranda tries to follow the convoluted explanation, but has a sinking feeling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did it say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the telescope?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you see anything, Shelley? Shelley glances around to make sure no one can hear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not tile that wall is made out of . It's a holographic screen. All part of your mission, isn't it? Miranda shakes her head, feeling foolish.     Walks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taps her forehead)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is all we have. The rest is dust.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete and Miranda stare at each other.     A tense beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was you I called that night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you mention that to the cops?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't think it would help you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What does that mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It means they wouldn't have let me treat you if they thought I had any kind of involvement in what happened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And did you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did I what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did I make it to your place?   Did I see you that night?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. We got disconnected and I couldn't get through to you. I sat there waiting all night. Figured you'd changed your mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why didn't you tell me this before?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because the only way you'll be able to accept these events is if you remember them on your own. My job is to assist you in processing that information because you're not in a frame of mind to do it by yourself.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She stares at him.     Queasy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're changing the subject.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The subject is you don't trust me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right now I don't trust anyone. She tries to read his face. Reminds herself of who Pete is and what he means to her. He points at her bandaged arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want to talk about today? She takes a resigned breath, slowly shakes her head. Wishing she could wake up from this nightmare:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to talk to my lawyer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think that's premature.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't help what you think.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SPRINKLER SYSTEMS doing their thing: THWIP, THWIP, THWIP... The female patients are out in the gardens for their freshly dose of air. BOOM DOWN TO Miranda alone at a bench. A cigarette appears before her, being offered to her:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You a Marlboro girl? Miranda sees Jenna looming above her, shielding the sun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't smoke, thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All we have is our health, cupcake. (sits beside her)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What I do is quit constantly, start again. Drives them all crazy. One day I quit three times.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh. Jenna lights her smoke, blows out the match slowly. Miranda turns and checks the building entrance as Jenna rambles on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They allow me one match at a time and pretend they're not watching. Check it out: salivating goon number one at three o'clock, oh- so-inconspicuous goon number two at five o'clock. Miranda follows Jenna's gaze. Sure enough, she's being closely watched by two orderlies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did you set on fire to wind up here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very perceptive, Doc. I burnt down the building where I worked. I found a baby at the doorstep, called the cops -- of course the bottom feeding pricks never showed. It's beside the point, really. Miranda shrugs. God knows what Jenna is talking about but who is she to say? Once again, Miranda checks the building entrance and now sees Parsons emerge. She rises --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil. He keeps walking.     Headed to the parking lot beyond.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil!

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He turns. His first instinct is to smile. But he checks himself, reminding himself of her new status. Slips into his best professional face:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Miranda.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wonder if I could talk to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course. (checks his watch)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, actually, I'm about to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your staff meeting's done and Thursdays you don't schedule sessions until the afternoon. This will just take one minute. Promise. Impressive.    She remembers his schedule perfectly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: True. (points)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But the Sheriff wants to ask me some questions. She follows his look to the parking lot where Sheriff Ryan emerges from his patrol car. Miranda nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's about Pete.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps he's not the most qualified person to be treating me. His tone is fatherly yet direct.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you complaining about his methods or are you referring to the nature of your past relationship with him? This surprises her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did he tell you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He explained there might be a conflict of interest because he has feelings for you. You two engaged in a kiss at one point. Am I right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told him we're all grownups here and the fact is he's the best doctor on my staff. As such, and given the severity of the charges you face, I consider him the most qualified person to assist your recovery. Now, if you'll excuse me, Sheriff Ryan is not a patient man. Stonewalled in the simplest of ways, she's left feeling like an idiot. Watches Parsons join the Sheriff by his car. The two men shake hands when suddenly Irene runs past her, yelling --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey!   Chloe! Now two ORDERLIES race past. Miranda looks over to see what the fuss is all about. Chloe is on top of an institute staff member we haven't seen before, a round black woman named CONSUELO. Punching her -- Other patients have crowded around the scuffle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You fucking cow giving me the evil eye, huh? Fuck you, you fuckin' voodoo witch -- ! Irene and the orderlies yank Chloe off Consuelo. Chloe ki and screams like an animal. Consuelo meekly stands up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (heavy Cuban accent)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is okay, she's okay -- she don't mean nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You bet your goddamn fat ass I mean it, you're a witch -- !!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McGrath, that's enough! The orderlies start pulling Chloe away.      Chloe spits Consuelo, full of venom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take your voodoo shit back to Cuba --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said that's enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Irene, she's okay. Pobrecita, la infeliz. It's a misunderstanding. Pobrecita. I was only trying to help her --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wanna help me? You pity me? (grabbing her crotch)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suck me. The orderlies haul Chloe off. Irene disperses the crowd. Consuelo sighs, embarrassed, wipes a bloody lip. Her manner says she just wants to get back to her duties. Excitement over, the patients resume whatever it is they were doing. Miranda stares at her bleak surroundings when something catches her eye: Pete watching her from his office window. He quickly slides the curtain shut. Odd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A sunny sky grows dark as night envelops us with a SWOOSH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SLOW PUSH DOWN empty corridors.      The air thick with d

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miranda cries softly, unable to sleep. VOICES trickle in from the corridor outside, wardens on their rounds, a SOFT MOAN from another cell, a random SCREAM. She shuts her eyes, repositions herself on her stomach.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: As before, somebody seems to be watching her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Irene escorts Miranda into the library.       A warden follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How are we feeling today?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'We'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry I asked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doesn't seem like the best choice of words when treating schizophrenics.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fitting right in, aren't you? The library is pretty    much empty at this hour except f the LIBRARIAN and the    odd janitor tidying up. An efficient-looking man    rises from a desk, briefcase in place, glass of water    -- this is attorney THEODORE "TEDDY" HOWARD.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miranda.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi. Irene checks her watch.       The warden hangs back, keep watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's due back in the rec room in twenty, Counselor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you kindly. Miranda sits.      Waits until Irene is out of hearing ra

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Teddy, I know you knew Doug well and this is an extremely --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm here as your lawyer. So whatever my relationship was with Doug is no longer of consequence. First things first, how are they treating you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like I'm crazy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know this place better than anyone. Anything out of the ordinary?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Other than me being crazy?   No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The DA is pushing for a hearing as soon as next week. They're eager to resolve this situation because -- well, crimes like this don't happen that often around here. Doug was a hometown boy who'd done good, beloved high school principal, a role model. Our best shot -- scratch that, our only shot -- is to claim temporary insanity. As he speaks, she starts fidgeting with her itchy bandage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait, wait, wait -- Teddy, you know me. I wouldn't raise a hand at my husband for the life of me. Not even in self-defense. Isn't it remotely possible a burglar broke in or some crazed high school student attacked Doug and I went into shock? Teddy shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're telling me there's no other suspects in anyone's mind?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frankly, no. Neighbors heard screams. They have you at the scene, they have the murder weapon and they have your prints everywhere. The only thing they don't have is motive. She keeps absently playing with the bandage. The adhesive is giving. The bandage starting to peel off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because there is no motive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And that's what's confusing them. The fact that you're a brilliant psychiatrist doesn't help either. It fills their heads with ideas. They figure if you were to plan a murder you might know how to fake insanity to get out of it. She pulls off half the bandage, back and forth. Not looking. BUT WE SEE the beginning of a pattern in her scarred skin --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not faking anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good. I pass no judgment either way. The point is --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The point is I'm the only person who doesn't believe I killed my husband. I never thought I'd say this, but I feel like I'm in the middle of a conspiracy. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you believe I'm crazy? An uncomfortable Teddy takes too long before answering. Miranda looks down, humiliated -- and now she sees it. Perfectly carved into her arm, her scar reads:

dialogues.speaker: "NOT ALONE."
dialogues.text: Petrified, Miranda jumps back, knocks down Teddy's glass of water all over his papers, her chair topples over. The warden and janitor look up -- Teddy tries for delicate:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It doesn't matter what I believe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forget it.   Forget I asked. PUSH INTO her face as involuntary tears roll down and we

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miranda. Numb. Pete trying hard to get through. A beat. We get a good look at the writing on her arm. (The right arm.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't help you if you don't talk to me. Silence from Miranda.     He is firm but not unkind:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can stand here all day. All week. You're the one running out of time. Nothing.     He goes to touch her arm.   She jerks it awa

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What does it mean? She shakes her head, at a loss. Torn between her suspicion and the need to confide in someone. Finally:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't write this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then who? They stare each other down. There's definitely chemistry between these two. But the moment is far from romantic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're going to have to trust me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because no matter what's going through your mind right now, I haven't done anything wrong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then you know exactly how I feel. He starts to speak, stops himself. Switches tactics. Their banter escalates in speed as their terms get more clinical:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You admit you're having a hard time differentiating what's reality from what's hallucination, right? So isn't it at least possible that --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As a doctor I agree with you. Maybe -- and this is a big maybe -- all of this is just a deep epilepsy that extends to the limbic structures, but I'm telling you --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about this moment right now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this a hallucination?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You tell me. But I do know what I sound like. Paranoia is the ultimate awareness, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which is why I suggest we simply increase your dose until --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (venom)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No!   Goddamnit! No! He steps back at her blowout. She catches the look on his face and forces herself to sit down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. Is there any way we can pretend that didn't just happen?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat; struggling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to believe you. I do. So I'll take your word for it -- you're not involved in this -- but you take mine: I didn't write this and I didn't kill my husband. He studies her.     Finally nods.   New tactic:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright. Let's say you didn't write this --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Number one: I'm right-handed. Number two: I would have had to bring an X-Acto knife into the shower to do this, wouldn't I? Pete tries to reserve judgment. Her argument has a certain loopy logic to it. He hesitates, then pulls a SERIES OF PHOTOGRAPHS from a manila envelope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think it's time you look at these. Miranda looks at the crime scene photos. Lurid. Terrible. Here's part of Doug's body. Here's the axe. And now she sees a closeup picture of the wall with words on it. In blood, a la Manson family. And it says:

dialogues.speaker: "NOT ALONE."
dialogues.text: Miranda immediately tosses it away from her.      Repulse

dialogues.speaker: FLASHBACK
dialogues.text: Miranda furiously writes on the wall with blood. Wipes her face breathlessly, leaving a thick red streak on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wrote that. Any idea why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (panic rising)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I didn't. No, I didn't!

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Pete retrieves the photograph off the floor and holds it up for her to study again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're the only person who can figure out what this means. Try to remember. Stop holding back. She nods meekly. Staring at the picture. Begins to shake as all of it finally comes flooding in --

dialogues.speaker: FLASHBACK
dialogues.text: A breathless Miranda wipes her face, leaving a thick streak of blood on it. She looks down at Doug, crawling on hands and knees. He moans horribly, in shock. She grabs the heavy axe from the floor and follows him. He reaches for the coffee table with the telephone on it and makes a move to grab it. He has all the speed of a dying turtle, and that's pretty much what he resembles. Miranda bites her lip, lifts the heavy axe with both hand Doug's hand grabs the phone. Miranda SWINGS THE AXE over her head and it comes down straight AT CAMERA. Miranda wipes her face again, catches her reflection in the mirror over the mantel and stares -- WE HEAR THAT SOUND. The WETTISH GURGLING sound. Miranda stares at the MIRROR looking for the source of it. For an instant we see the teenage girl's reflection there, beckoning. But now she's gone and Miranda is left studying her own demented expression and now FLAMES RISE around her. She looks down at her feet: No fire. Blood on her clothes, axe still in her hands. Looks back up at:

dialogues.speaker: THE MIRROR VERSION OF MIRANDA
dialogues.text: shows a serene expression on her face. Fire enveloping her. She slowly lifts her hands over her head. In place of the axe there are CHAINS attached to SHACKLES on her wrists. She is completely naked, as if purified -- like an extreme version of Anima Sola. (A Biblical icon in which a woman in fiery purgatory awaits her fate.) Time stands still for a mesmerizing moment -- When the MIRROR SHATTERS TO PIECES and we're back to reality. Miranda stares at the axe she's flung at it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miranda tries to wash off the blood in the sink. This is a daunting task, seeing as how she's covered in it. She stares at her bloody footprints all over the floor, at the marks on the door handle, towels and wall. Gasping for breath, almost crying, she turns on the shower at full blast and climbs into the tub. She watches the blood wash off her. As if finally coming back to her body and realizing what she's done, she slowly slides down the shower wall and curls up in the tub. Crying. Shaking.     She shuts her eyes as hard as she can to make it all go away, and we --

dialogues.speaker: BLACKNESS
dialogues.text: Silence. And now, faintly at first, but GROWING PROGRESSIVELY LOUDER, we hear the SOUND OF BUZZING FLIES.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miranda wakes up, still in the tub. How long has she been there, hours? Days? Impossible to know. But at some point she must have turned off the water. She sits up, every muscle of her body aching, hair caked with blood. The first thing that hits her is the stench. And it's fou the putrid smell of decaying flesh. She steps gingerly ou of the tub onto the flooded floor and follows the trail o blood, mortified at what she will find.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Soon enough the press will make the Manson Family reference, but for now, only Miranda is here to witness the fruit of her labor. She gasps for air. Instead she is hit by a wave of nausea. She doubles over to throw up when there is a FRANTIC RAPPING at the front door. She freezes. VOICES and YELLS trickle in. The HINGES on the door RATTLE under REPEATED POUNDING and she still stands there as the first FIREMAN breaks in. Sheriff Ryan and his deputies right behind. A concerned Pete Graham behind them.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The cops take one look at the place and raise their guns at her, but we can't hear what they're saying because Miranda's ragged BREATHING has taken over the soundtrack. Suffice to say that, at the sight of the guns, something clicks inside her and she turns on her heel and flees --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She slips on blood, nearly falls as she scrambles to the bedroom --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She locks the door behind her, hyperventilating in terror Instantly there are men POUNDING on it. SQUAWKING RADIOS. ORDERS BARKED at her. She spots two officers through the window in her backyard. About to smash the window. A caged animal, completely surrounded, she covers her fac with her hands. Trembling. The doorknob jiggles violently about to give. And when she brings her hands down she is staring straight into the teenage girl's face. And she OPENS HER MOUTH WIDE and now we are back in --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miranda gasps for air, drowning in sensory overload.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh God, oh God, oh God... She rocks back and forth. Finally aware of what she's done. She is the killer. No more doubts. And now that she knows, everything is much worse. A long, harrowing beat. WE PUSH IN ON her devastated face.       NIGHT TURNS TO D

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The locks are unlocked. Pete appears at the door. Miranda glances up at him. She looks like a different person. Completely destroyed. He crouches beside her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You okay? She shakes her head slowly. He sets his hand on her shoulder. She turns to him and hugs him tight, holding on for dear life. Breaks down in sobs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Parsons leafs through Miranda's file.   Pete stands by th window, lost in thought. PARSONS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much does she remember? PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It all came flooding back last night. PARSONS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guilt? PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More like an uncontrollable reminiscence. Intense, over- cathected. She's not feeling guilty of her actions, not exactly. Sounds to me like last night she actually re-lived them in great detail. PARSONS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hypermnesis following amnesia. Could a specific epileptic element be involved? PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's exactly what she suggested. Even in her present state, her instincts remain impeccable. PARSONS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd like to talk to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete escorts a fragile Miranda down the corridor.    The two orderlies walking ominously behind them. PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Standard procedure. MIRANDA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't say a word.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Parsons on the phone, gestures for them to enter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dorothy, I can't discuss this now -- (motions for them to sit)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not taking it lightly, no.   We will talk about it at home. Miranda and Pete sit across from him. Miranda trying hard to appear composed -- acutely aware of her every gesture, and of how different her last visit to this office was. Nothing casual about it now. She stares at the picture frames on Phil's desk (all facing AWAY FROM us), the diplomas on the wall, the books by noted fathers of neurology (works by Hughlings Jackson, Kurt Goldstein, Henry Head, A.R. Luria). A framed quote reads: "'If You Do Know That Here Is One Hand, We'll Grant You All The Rest.' -- Wittgenstein"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, dear. Me too. He hangs up. Takes a moment to look at Miranda. Tries a smile but to her it comes off condescending. Fact is -- there's nothing to smile about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm so sorry about this, Miranda. She nods, dazed. Angles her head to look at a framed picture on his desk. Parsons looks to Pete.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Has Pete told you about the hearing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Teddy already filled her in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Teddy Howard is top notch. He's going to do everything in his power -- and he's quite resourceful -- to prove you're not fit to stand trial. Miranda, I know you have no family left, so we're your family now and we're all going down to the wire to protect you and help you in any way we --

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: PUSH IN ON Miranda who stares intently at something on the desk. Not listening to a word he's saying --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is that? Parsons pauses here.      Exchanges glances with Pete.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The girl in the picture. WE SEE what she is talking about: a framed photograph on the desk is now FACING us. Eerie. It shows Parsons, his wife Dorothy and a young girl. Our teenage girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My daughter. Miranda looks up at this, perplexed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's the girl I saw.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're obviously mistaken.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm positive. She was hurt, bleeding. Is she all right? Pete and Parsons trade uneasy looks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miranda, you've seen that photograph at least a dozen times, every time you've been in this office. You're just confused --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not about this. Is she all right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, she's not... all right. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rachel committed suicide six years ago. This shuts Miranda right up.      Mind spinning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miranda, that's none of your --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's okay. (to Miranda)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rachel was a very troubled girl. Handicapped since birth. She was born mute. My wife and I tried everything to help her fit in but... but she ran away from home more than once, wanting to end her life. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And she finally succeeded. Jumped off Ashley Bridge. She was only seventeen years old. Ashley Bridge. Mute. Ghost? Miranda hesitates here. She is not the type to believe in ghosts, and knows full well what even her suggestion of it will sound like.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm -- I'm terribly sorry, Phil. Parsons doesn't want to talk about it anymore.    Rises.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter, can I speak to you? The men step outside. PUSH IN ON Miranda's face as she stares at the picture of Rachel. We catch snippets of the doctors' discussion outside, increasing her paranoia --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Textbook psychotic pattern... manifestation of guilt...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... much she knows about Rachel?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm telling you she doesn't... Concocted alternate reality...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm trusting you... crawling with cops. A DARK SHADOW envelops Miranda's confused face, as we --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miranda's pale skin is visible in the dim monochromatic light. We are MOVING TOWARDS her, seeing her as if from the POV of someone approaching her. We become aware of the RAGGED BREATHING sound. Miranda opens her eyes, looks this way and that, then closes them again. She is nearly asleep when she hears a sound we've heard before. The strained WET SOUND. Miranda's eyes SNAP OPEN. She slowly sits up, back against the wall. Squinting to cover every inch of the room. And now she sees it: a SHADOW crouched in the corner. Roughly the size of a person. Miranda climbs off the bed and slowly walks towards it. Scared, but determined. She wrinkles her nose at the putrid smell coming from it. She gets closer... closer... The RAGGED BREATHING GROWING LOUDER as she reaches the shadow -- She stretches out her hand and finally touches... NOTHING. She swipes her hand through the air, feeling stupid. MIRANDA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is not going to work. I'm sick of being watched, and I know this place well and it doesn't smell this bad. She paces around the room, feels the wall, taps her head. MIRANDA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm awake, I'm not dreaming. I'm alive -- this is not some afterlife mumbo jumbo. So-called paranormal activity can be debunked a million different ways. So whatever you are, whatever it is I'm making up here -- I'm letting you go, I'm setting you free. I'm the wrong person. And I need to sleep. I'm not afraid and I don't believe and I'm fully aware that this is all in my mind -- fiction -- a concocted alternate reality -- and I acknowledge it. And now I'm done with it. I'm going to sleep now. The moment is as brave as it is ridiculous. She has psyched herself into verbally defeating the ghost. And now she climbs back in bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sleepy)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Besides, if you really were the ghost of Rachel Parsons, you would let me out of this cell. A beat. And now we hear the SOUND OF THE DEADBOLT SLIDE OPEN. The door opens quietly. PUSH INTO Miranda's face. Properly scared now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holy shit. If proof is what she wanted, proof is what she got.   Fro now on we'll refer to the teenage girl as RACHEL.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miranda takes a tentative step outside her cell, feeling the door with her fingers, feeling along the wall -- still making sure she isn't dreaming this. She looks down the long, empty corridor, the glare of neon lights making her readjust her eyes momentarily. Nobody there. But when she looks down the other way she sees a pair of bare feet disappear behind the wall. So quick we're not sure we saw it for sure. Miranda deliberately walks in the opposite direction. At night the clinical corridor takes on an unsettling quality. She silently strolls down the hall, tilting her head at the various sounds from PATIENTS in their cells. She turns to make sure Rachel isn't behind her and when Miranda faces forward again, she realizes she is standing right across from:

dialogues.speaker: THE NURSES' STATION
dialogues.text: Where two nurses are watching TELEVISION. Miranda tiptoes past them, ducking at the window to remain unseen.

dialogues.speaker: ANOTHER CORRIDOR
dialogues.text: This one is wider. Miranda is startled by the sudden sound of LAUGHTER behind her. The nurses laughing at their late night show. Momentarily distracted, she almost knocks over a mop and bucket resting by the wall. She holds the mop in place and now opens the door to a SANITATION CLOSET.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She looks for something, a tool. Discards a pair of brushes and finds a small screwdriver. Pockets it.

dialogues.speaker: THE STAIRS
dialogues.text: Miranda hurries up the stairs, hugging the wall to stay clear from the SURVEILLANCE CAMERA sweeping the area. She waits at the landing, times it just right -- and scurries to the next floor.

dialogues.speaker: ACTION
dialogues.text: Knowing her way around here, Miranda keeps a steady pace as she heads towards her old office. She turns a corner and stops in her tracks: another JANITOR making his rounds. She waits until he's out of sight and rushes to her office. She pulls out the stolen screwdriver and brings it to the lock. Starts unscrewing the screws. She does this as fast as she can, but she's no professional -- so it takes a few tries. She loosens one screw, then another -- and clumsily drops the screwdriver. The METAL ECHOES against the floor. Miranda sucks her breath in, waits. No footsteps. She bends down, retrieves it, and holds onto the knob for balance. It easily turns in her hand. It was open all along. She simply forgot to check.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miranda shuts the door behind her and slips behind her computer. Shrouded in darkness. Hits a switch and a SURVEILLANCE MONITOR comes to life. Now she has a view of the corridors: two guards here, a nurse going for a smoke, a janitor at the coffee machine and so on. She switches on her computer and taps her fingers as she waits for it to boot up.

dialogues.speaker: ON SURVEILLANCE MONITOR
dialogues.text: The JANITOR with his coffee cup now heading back towards Miranda's office corridor --

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Miranda glances at the door, can see the glare of the computer screen reflecting against the glass pane. She tries opening drawers but they're all locked. She remembers something and digs a sweatshirt from beneath the couch, uses it to block the light. Computer powered up, she runs an online search for "RACHEL PARSONS." Waits as the info appears --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to self)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright. What happened to you?

dialogues.speaker: ON COMPUTER SCREEN
