dialogues.text: Various listings: The archive news of her funeral, something about her search and a LOCAL NEWS ARTICLE about teen suicide. That's the one she chooses. Hits "PRINT." She checks the surveillance monitor again:     the janito now mops right outside her door.

dialogues.speaker: ON PRINTOUT
dialogues.text: The heading says "WHAT DRIVES OUR TEENAGERS TO SUICIDE?" A quick glimpse gives us ages (16, 18, 17) and names of three local girls who have died. Rachel's name and PHOTOGRAPH appears with two others: Jenny Dixon and Andrea White. Miranda pockets it, looks back at the surveillance monitor: the janitor is walking away. She watches him disappear down the hall. Slowly but surely. And now the screen is empty. But just for a second. Because suddenly Rachel is there. Staring straight at her. Makes us jump.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Retracing her steps, Miranda shuts her door and hits the stairs. Playing off the sweep of the surveillance camera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As she reaches the landing, she hears VOICES coming her way. She detours down another corridor and hides from view. Waits for Consuelo and a nurse to exit down the staircase.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: And now she turns at ANOTHER SOUND. Coming from inside the room immediately behind her. Room 237. She steps to the small glass pane on the door and peers inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It takes a moment to adjust our eyes to the darkness but now we make out TWO FIGURES in the room involved in some sort of struggle. Miranda presses her face against the glass and now sees a flash of metal. Something sharp. Not a knife, but a needl And now a blur of hair yanked up by a strong arm. In the light we can make out Chloe, eyes glazed, drooling. Just for a beat, because now she is slapped down on the bed like a rag doll and the man with the needle ENTERS FRAME.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miranda flinches, confused. Glances down the corridor to ensure she remains undiscovered. Then peers back in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chloe on her stomach on the bed. Her pale naked skin marked with scratches and bruises. The needle is stuck in her arm, which hangs off the side. Her mouth is open but it is impossible to tell whether she is laughing or sobbing. Abruptly the man climbs on her, pulling off his T-shirt. As he discards it we see that it is yellow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Disturbed, Miranda turns away. Except now the corridor isn't empty. There is a JANITOR at the end. Coffee cup in hand. Staring at her, disconcerted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey! Miranda turns and runs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miranda bolts down the stairs. THUNDERING FOOTSTEPS and YELLS can be heard right behind her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miranda races down the empty floor towards an emergency exit door all the way at the end. TWO ORDERLIES emerge from the staircase and give chase, shouting for her to stop. PATIENTS holler from their cells, awakened by the COMMOTION. Miranda's heart is nearly bursting through her chest as she gets closer and closer to the emergency door. Twenty feet, fifteen, ten -- When a side door opens and a MAN IN A YELLOW SHIRT appears, blocking her path. Miranda tries to avoid crashing into him but carries too much momentum. Veers left against the wall but the man easily tackles her and pins her down. The orderlies and an nurse arrive at the scene to find her screaming, hysterical. They hold her down -- MIRANDA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's him! It's him! Jesus Christ, it's him! The man in the yellow shirt acts as if he has no idea what she's talking about. Ho-hum, just another psychotic woman trying to escape. A nurse prepares a needle and we --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRACKING ALONG a long desk where the staff finish their morning meeting. Parsons, Pete and Irene among others. PARSONS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've transferred her to a higher security room on the fifth floor. That's my final concession to any type of special treatment. PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the night staff? IRENE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They insist her room was properly locked, what else could they say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could there be any truth to her claim?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter, we have one hundred and forty employees. Thirty-five work maintenance. They all wear yellow shirts, it's their uniform. I'm holding a very discreet inquiry, sure -- but I don't want a news van parked outside day and night. It makes much more sense that she tried to escape and got caught, doesn't it? Pete ponders this.     It certainly seems that way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I perused Miranda's files on Chloe McGrath -- they're damn comprehensive. Maybe she was a bit obsessed with her. Irene and Parsons share a look.     He wraps it up:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The scariest gift God gave us is our minds. And a bright person like Miranda -- she's grasping at straws here -- who knows what her brain is telling her, now that it's snapped.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A better room, in fact. This one has a view. Heavy bars on the windows, but still. Miranda paces. Pete is seated, observing her deteriorating state.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you live here when Rachel killed herself?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. As a matter of fact, I was part of the search party that found the body.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil must have been a wreck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can imagine. Actually, Phil was in Houston undergoing triple bypass surgery when it happened. What was that?     Miranda reacts to this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And this is confirmed. There are hospital records and so forth?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure there are.   Can we get back on track now? Miranda pulls out the folded printout from her pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about these other dates, was Phil here when the other girls went missing and found dead? A disconcerted Pete looks at the article with the pictures of Rachel and the others: Andrea White and Jenny Dixon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are you going with this? First I'm a suspect in Doug's death, now what, Phil Parsons murdered his own daughter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rachel Parsons disappeared six years ago. A week later she's a suicide. Andrew White, four years ago, same M.O., and Jenny Dixon, two years ago. Don't you find that unusual? He regards her. Maybe Parsons is right: she's desperately grasping at straws now. Skims the article:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What same M.O.? One jumped off a bridge, one hung herself and one crashed her car. Who gave you this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not one left a suicide note. In fact, how is anybody sure these were suicides?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You heard Phil, his daughter had tried several times before --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's his story. I need to talk to the reporter who wrote that. Frank something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you can't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I beg to differ. I know my visitation rights.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't because... he died. Miranda snaps to attention here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're telling me the one local investigative reporter who connected three highly-suspicious deaths, just happens to have conveniently died?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank Albright was an eighty-year- old retired sociology professor. (re: the article)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a fluff piece about teenage depression and the breakdown of the nuclear family. You can find one in any local paper, anywhere, any other week!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be smug, Pete. That's one thing you've never been. Rachel is somehow connected to what I'm going through. I don't know how -- like you said, I'm not in a frame of mind to process the information without assistance. So I'm asking you for assistance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen to me. You are not well. I had hoped once you remembered the murder we could deal with your feelings about it but these fixations:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rachel Parsons, Chloe McGrath -- are self-created distractions to avoid looking into yourself. And the longer you --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know this lecture like the back of my hand!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good.   Saves me the trouble. Discussion over. He raps on the door. Triple-locks come unlocked and an ORDERLY is there. Peter exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter hurries down the corridor, passing by a nurse. The same one who bandaged Miranda earlier, so let's give her a proper name: CLAIRE. She pushes her cart into the elevator.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Claire and her cart emerge from the elevator and she heads down the long corridor, reaches a door and unlocks it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TIGHT ON a row of drug-filled shelves. Claire parks her cart and kicks off her shoes. Digs a pack of smokes out of her stashed purse when a pair of hands grab her. Claire squeaks until she sees her attacker: a stoner type named SIMON. Deftly unbuttoning her uniform, hands all over her. She means to resist but he's got such boyish charm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get off me, you dog --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hell, don't go all bubbly with joy or anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't be in here and you know it. Nap in your car.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She finally twists herself out of his grasp. Points an accusing finger, but she's grinning. Blushing, even.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now get out before we get busted. Properly reprimanded, Simon picks up his folded uniform and prepares to leave, head hung low.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You slay me, Claire.    Honest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure I do, Boy Scout. He exits.    She shakes her head, slips her uniform back on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Simon presses the button, waits. He checks inside his folded uniform where we see several stolen vials of sedatives. The doors begin to close when --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold it, Simon! He hides the loot behind his back, busted.       She hold door open and tosses him his yellow shirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you think I am, laundry service?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (relieved)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Won't happen again, ma'am. She turns and exits.     The doors slide shut.   Meet our rapist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bustling with activity. The room is divided into two: large main area where the patients eat, plus a second, smaller upstairs area for the staff. BOOM DOWN to find Miranda eating at a long table. Shelley beside her, playing with her plastic fork. Jenna taps an unlit cigarette. As usual, Irene keeps watch nearby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... She'd get high on glue and make me help her try on my bras. Is that the strangest shit you've heard?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heard stranger. But she's a case.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And she always put on a happy face. Man, what an optometrist. Optometrist?     Miranda starts to correct her, but lets go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You narced her out, didn't you? Boo-hoo. Bet you were a little buzzed yourself. Miranda's gaze strays from this, um, most compelling of conversations and comes to rest on Chloe. Alone at another table. Heavily sedated. A wreck. Miranda rises and walks over. Shelley waits until she's out of hearing range, leans in to Jenna --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All work, that woman.   Work, work, work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's like an alcoholic.   But with work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What work?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not safe to tell you.   Wish I could. Jenna rolls her eyes, returns to her food.

dialogues.speaker: UPSTAIRS
dialogues.text: Parsons watches intrigued as Miranda sits beside Chloe and starts talking. From Parson's POV up above we can see pretty much the entire dining area.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO MIRANDA
dialogues.text: Trying to get Chloe's attention. But Chloe just stares at her untouched food, glassy-eyed. MIRANDA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I saw what happened. I'm sorry. No reaction. MIRANDA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you told anyone?   Chloe? Nothing. MIRANDA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, Chloe -- the person who did this to you is not the devil. And if you can identify him, I'll make sure the motherfucker is arrested. Now Chloe looks at her, like something finally registers. CHLOE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doctor, did you just say 'motherfucker'? MIRANDA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know his name? Maybe you saw a nametag on his uniform? Think. Chloe simply stares.    Finally shakes her head. CHLOE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man, you must really hate me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?   I don't hate you. CHLOE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You hate me because now you're just the same as me. You must feel so embarrassed. MIRANDA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't hate you. And I don't feel embarrassed. CHLOE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's just a pat answer you have because you're new at this. Trust me, I know what I'm talking about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rising)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forget it, alright? Forget we had this conversation. Chloe abruptly grabs her arm.     Tightly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what happens next?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I get the distinct feeling you're going to tell me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The shock wears off and the guilt kicks in. And that guilt is the real motherfucker. You'll be watched 24/seven, because they're afraid you'll kill yourself. Dr. Graham will question every harmless gesture, every innocent comment, ever twitch you make and eventually -- and it's a fucking tedious 'eventually' -- you'll stop hating yourself for what you did. But what replaces that hatred is this unbearable sadness. And you don't lose that as long as you live. PUSH IN ON Miranda.     Deeply affected by Chloe's words, we --

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA'S RESIGNED DAILY GRIND IN QUICK DISSOLVES --
dialogues.text: A) Miranda and the other patients line up for meds in the rec room. B) Irene keeps watch in the garden as the women get their daily fresh air. C) Wardens watch as each patient enters their cell at night and the lights go off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Echoing an earlier scene, we are MOVING TOWARDS her -- her pale skin visible in the dim monochromatic light. Miranda flicks a look this way and that, alert. Sensing something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leave me alone. Go away. Just like a crazy person. She listens for any further noise, hears none and shuts her eyes. Exhausted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've lost my fucking mind.   Happy now? Silence. But now the BEDSPRINGS CREAK behind her and she whips around and starts to scream as a big hand covers her mouth. Her eyes open wide at the sight of Simon, in his yellow shirt. He shoves her against the mattress and presses his full weight against her. She lets out a muffled scream as he uncaps a syringe with his teeth and brings the plunger to her throat. Straight into her jugular.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sotto)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is gonna hurt you more than it hurts me. She flails and kicks desperately but he pins her down. The BEDSPRINGS STRAIN violently and now he's straddling her, squeezing the plunger into her throat. Her eyes welling up:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sotto)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've always wanted to do a doctor. She manages to free one hand and yanks the syringe from her throat. It flies to the floor. He grins, enjoying this:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sotto)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The more you fight me, the harder I get, pussycat -- so pretty please, with sugar on top -- keep still. Simon paws at her clothes as she struggles to defend herself. He finally slaps her free arm down. Presses his knee against it, immobilizing her once more. Now he produces another syringe from his pocket. Checks it. Miranda shakes her head, pleading. A scream stuck in her throat. But nobody can hear her. Simon brings the syringe towards her when suddenly we hear a LOUD CLANGING at the door. Shaking it off its hinges.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Simon looks up, confused. Nobody is there. The split- second distraction is all Miranda needs to shove him off the bed. She fumbles for the discarded syringe and STABS HIS CHEST WITH IT -- squeezes the plunger --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sotto)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take that, son of a bitch. Simon moans as the full dose hits his system and his body goes limp. Miranda exhales, coming back to herself. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rachel? No response.     Miranda grabs his keys, begins to undres him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: shows a uniformed janitor calmly walking down the corridor. PULL BACK to see we are in --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bank of monitors keep watch on the premises   after dar TWO GUARDS play cards (Uno), bored to tears.    A cursory glance at the monitors produces no reaction.    Certainly janitor walking down the corridor is no cause   for alarm

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dead quiet. CRICKETS CHIRP or whatever it is    crickets do. Miranda steadies her breathing, perusing    rows of unfamiliar cars. She clicks Simon's key-ring    button repeatedly until a set of headlights blink on   and off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miranda slips behind the wheel, STARTS the CAR. The RADIO KICKS IN at EAR-DEAFENING VOLUME. She nearly drops dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The gate GUARD reads a magazine as Miranda's stolen car approaches. The guard barely registers the driver in the booth mirror, immersed in his article. Hits a button to open the gate for him. It opens SLOWLY. S-l-o-w-l-y.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: Miranda, sweating, watches the receding image of the institute behind her. Turns on the main road. Free. MIRANDA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, thank you, thank you. She glances back, makes sure no one is following her. Catches her own reflection in the rearview mirror: the scared eyes, the haunted face. The new version of herself. She flips the RADIO dial: BAD NEW AGE MUZAK. BAD COUNTRY. BAD DISCO. More BAD NEW AGE MUZAK. She finds IGGY POP'S entirely appropriate "THE PASSENGER) and lets it play.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now we are seeing her as if from the POV of someone traveling alongside the car. Peering THROUGH the passenger window. Miranda becomes aware of this, slowly glances over. Sees nothing but her own reflection. Turns back forward. We NOTICE the blue cigarette lighter key chain dangling off the dashboard. Nothing but a long stretch of road ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The neighborhood perfectly quiet late at night. Miranda parks in the driveway and stares at the empty house. Steels herself, climbs out of the car and heads around back. She finds her SPARE KEY behind a potted plant, takes a deep breath and lets herself in through the back door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: POLICE CRIME-SCENE TAPE everywhere. She turns on the kitchen light only and scurries to her bedroom without even looking in the direction of the living room, avoiding the scene of the gruesome crime altogether. Eerie as hell --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miranda stuffs clothes into a suitcase, finds her passpor digs out some cash from a box. Quick change of clothes to get rid of the rapist's uniform. Fast, fast, fast --

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: Miranda watches her house fade from view in the rearview mirror as she drives down the block. Shudders. Flips the RADIO dial with shaky hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Weather forecasters predict heavy winds tonight as a major thunderstorm rolls in tomorrow. You're listening to KLPG, 101.4 on your dial. This next honky-tonk heartbreak classic is... She looks in the rearview mirror once more.      Only thi time she is met by a piercing pair of eyes. Rachel's.     Inside the car. Rachel's mouth opens unnaturally wide, revealing a gaping abyss of rotted teeth and flesh -- and lets out the wet sound. A threatening howl this time, pure venom. Miranda covers her face, jerks the car. It does a 180 and slides to a halt in the middle of the street -- Facing the direction of her house again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miranda jumps out, panicked. Glances around. Looks inside the car: no Rachel. A beat to catch her breath, making up her mind. Slides behind the wheel and makes a U-turn.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUOUS ACTION
dialogues.text: Miranda flips the rearview mirror so it faces the ceiling and turns UP the RADIO. GUNS the pedal. Freaked. She's driven maybe 20 feet when suddenly her ENGINE DIES

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. The CAR SPUTTERS to a stop. Miranda goes to turn the key but suddenly freezes. Looks at the ignition oddly and notices the key is gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why are you doing this to me? A dead-still beat. Glancing around, she is even more startled to see the blue lighter key chain lying in the middle of the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miranda opens her car door and walks down the empty street to retrieve her suddenly magical keys. We watch her reach the keys, all alone out here. The moment she bends down to pick it up she is blinded by the glare of HEADLIGHT and the ROAR OF AN ENGINE. Miranda jumps out of the way, narrowly avoiding being flattened by a ROAD SWEEPER, spraying water as it goes. She watches the truck disappear down the block. Heart in her throat. Calms her nerves and now walks over to the pesky keys again. Smack in the middle of a puddle now. BOOM UP the posts harnessing power lines which surround the area until we STOP ON a pair of INDUSTRIAL BOLTS fastened around the insulators of a thick power line. From here we see Miranda bend down and pick up her keys. And now the bolts suddenly shake off their hinges, coming loose right in front of our eyes -- moved by some invisible force -- Miranda tilts her head at the sound of a METALLIC SNAP and turns. The bolts pop out of their sockets. The LIVE WIRE uncoils like some gigantic serpent and swings straight towards the paralyzed Miranda -- She looks down at her feet, ankle-deep in the puddle, back up at the 11,000 VOLTS OF POWER about to fry her to a crisp and jumps out of the way at the last second. The wire hits the water and the monumental charge sends SPARKS flying in every direction. It looks like lightning. A silent, sudden beat.   That was as close as close gets. MIRANDA (fighting tears)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you want from me? No sign of Rachel. Miranda yells at the air, glancing over her shoulder, seemingly demented: MIRANDA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it you want me to do?!! A moment. Miranda stranded. The stolen car in the middle of the road. And now the SQUEAK of a GATE OPENING abruptly. Miranda whips her head in the direction of the sound. It's the front gate to her house. And now the front door SWINGS OPEN. And now the living room LIGHTS switch on.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Clearly Rachel wants her back in the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't. (softly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, please don't make me go back in there. But even as she's saying this her feet are moving towards it. She pauses, looks at the car in the middle of the road. Looks at the fizzling puddle where she was almost electrocuted. No neighbors have come out to investigate yet, but how long can that last? She walks to the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miranda climbs in, not sure whether to laugh or cry here. She's never asked a ghost for permission before:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bear with me, I'm just parking it out of the way so it won't look suspicious in the middle of the road -- okay. She STARTS the ENGINE and pulls over to the sidewalk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miranda stands in her living room, staring at her handiwork. Frozen with dread. The blood has been cleaned up some, but the mess remains. The upturned furniture covered in plastic, the chalk outline of the body, the yellow crime-scene tape, the shattered mirror above the fireplace, the muddied footprints of dozens of cops, coroners, etc. The faded writing on the wall:       "NOT ALONE." Miranda takes it all in, not entirely sure what she's supposed to be looking for.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (piecing it together)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not alone. What happened to you happened to other girls. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I understand. And I'm sorry. But there is nothing I can do about it now. It has nothing to do with me.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Not knowing what else to do, she turns to exit when the TELEVISION SET suddenly COMES TO LIFE, making her jump. The unmistakable MUSIC from some old WB cartoon at FULL BLAST. She stares at the TV screen. Is there some sign here she should be able to follow? She crosses to turn it off and immediately doubles over in pain --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit. She looks at her foot. A big SHARD OF GLASS is stuck right through the flimsy hospital slipper into her skin. Blood already seeping from the nasty cut --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miranda seated on the edge of the tub, slowly pulls out the piece of glass, drops it in the wastebasket. She grabs a cotton ball and alcohol and starts cleaning the cut. And now, FAINT at first, but GROWING LOUDER -- she hears the hollow WET SOUND we've come to associate with Rachel. Inside the room with her -- Miranda stares at the medicine cabinet. Did the mirror move? We watch her from the MIRROR POV as she holds perfectly still, listening. The SOUND now seems to have STOPPED. A silent beat. She turns her attention back to cleaning her cut, grimaci as the alcohol burns her skin. It looks painful. And now the slow SQUEAK of the MEDICINE CABINET DOOR make her look up again. And she sees herself in the mirror lik the night of the slaughter: flames all around her. Naked arms raised. Wrists shackled. Anima Sola. She stares.     Mesmerized.    The sound of FLAMES GROWIN LOUDER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.   No.   No... Miranda walks slowly to the mirror. Incredibly, the image reflecting back at her also grows bigger. As if the two versions of her are literally walking towards each other. FROM A SIDE ANGLE WE SEE both their faces mere inches apart. Miranda brings her fingertips to the mirror and touches it. Immediately pulls her hand back.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Miranda stares at her fingertips. The tips are burnt. The skin sizzles softly. 200 percent scientifically impossible. And when she looks up at the mirror again -- the image is gone. It is now deathly quiet. And what she finds herself staring at in the mirror is the reflection of something just behind her. A folded newspaper discarded in the far corner of the room. She turns to look at it now. It's opened to the REALTY LISTINGS page. Doug must have left it there. She picks it up and looks closer: Focusing on a picture of a bank- repossessed property. The address is in Willows Creek. Her brain wires start clicking. This must be what Rachel wanted her to see. She stares at it. PUSH IN ON the picture as we --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A "FOR SALE" sign still flapping in the wind.   The first few rays of light break through the dawn sky. Miranda's (Simon's) car approaches up the road until it FILLS the FRAME and parks. Miranda steps out. She studies the house before walking up the drive. We watch her peek through windows and walk around back, looking for something. What exactly, we don't know. (Neither does she.) She makes her way back to the starting point and fixes her stare now on the barn. The one place he hasn't looked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dark, empty. The WIND outside causes the ALUMINUM SIDING to FLAP NOISILY. It's slightly unnerving, but hey, it's just the wind. Miranda covers the distance of the large room, perplexed. There is something about this place. Something she can't quite put her finger on. Beckoning her. With a last fruitless look, she heads towards the front door when a glint of mental in the opposite corner stops her. She moves to it.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: And here, where the walls should meet, there is a narrow gap, leading to a passage, maybe five inches wide. A padlocked chain has been threaded through a hole in both walls, holding them together. Miranda inspects the heavy padlock, the source of the glint. She tugs on the wall and opens it to the limits of the chain, but that's only a few inches more. Miranda peers into the darkness beyond, but can't see a thing. Hesitating only a moment, she turns sideways and slides herself into the claustrophobic slot. She moves forward cautiously a few feet until her face brushes against something hanging in the air. She stops, startled. It's a pull-string hanging from a naked light bulb. She tugs on it. And now she has 60 watts of reddish glow to see the hatch on the floor immediately in front of her. She pulls on the LATCH and it opens with a RUSTY CREAK. She peers into the pitch-black basement below. Feels around for the beginning of a stepladder and climbs down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miranda emerges from the ladder into total darkness. Whatever dim reddish light was provided by the bulb upstairs does not reach here. She feels around the wall for a switch. Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to self)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not shrink-appropriate to be afraid of the dark, right? Abruptly there's a sharp CLICK as she lights Simon's key- chain lighter, and the wavery light illuminates the vast space. Rats scurry for cover. It takes a second to orient ourselves. Something metallic catches the lighter's reflection way in back. Miranda walks towards it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello? She takes a few more steps until her foot hits a bulk on the floor. She stops. Kneels down and in the dim half- light we make out a backpack. She unzips it and rifles through it (T-shirts, underwear, Walkman) until she finds a wallet. Opens the billfold and brings the lighter next to the ID: the picture belongs to a teenager named

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is there anybody here?   Hello? The lighter in her hand is getting hot, so she lets it click off. When it comes back on we see she has wrapped a ragged T-shirt around it for insulation. Miranda steps deeper into the room. Up ahead, she can make out the metallic thing that reflected light before. It is a hook in the ceiling. And suspended from it are several heavy chains. Like a meat rack. And now she catches a whiff of the terrible smell and sees the body of the teenage girl: hanging upside down, tied around the hands and ankles. Medical training kicking in, Miranda quickly lowers the girl to the ground, causing the angry rats to skitter away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go away!   Fuck off! (We see the following in between flicks of the lighter so that we go from midnight black to wavery light in an almost strobe-light effect:) She checks for vital signs, pulse, heartbeat -- Miranda's adrenaline at full tilt --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon, c'mon, c'mon -- She strikes the flint and brings the lighter to the girl's pupils. Inspects them. Slaps her repeatedly, clinically. The strobe effect also allows us glimpses of the immediate surroundings:   household tools strewn about; wire cutters, pliers -- a pool of dried blood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wake up, Tracy, wake up -- Nothing. She unties the wires around the girl's ankles. The skin swollen grotesquely around them. She shakes the girl. Slowly coming to the realization that it's too late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miranda comes crashing out of the barn, doubles over and throws up. The bright light outside blinding her momentarily. Her bloodshot eyes taking a moment to register --

dialogues.speaker: THE PATROL CAR
dialogues.text: parked in front of the house. A POLICE OFFICER cautiously peering inside her stolen car. He looks up and notices her. Miranda hesitates. Nowhere to run.      The officer waves His name is TURLINGTON. OFFICER TURLINGTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Howdy there. He says this while already strolling over.        Miranda mind races a mile a minute -- OFFICER TURLINGTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything okay? MIRANDA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Y-yes. OFFICER TURLINGTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That your vehicle, ma'am? She stares at the young, friendly cop. His left hand resting on his belt. Right next to his gun. But it seems as if he has no idea who she is. At least not yet. MIRANDA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes -- I -- I just pulled over.     I was -- looking for a bathroom. Morning sickness, you know... OFFICER TURLINGTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Congratulations. But I'm afraid this is private property -- you can't just waltz on in. You understand that. She nods, nerves shot to hell.     Starts walking. MIRANDA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be on my merry way now. My husband will never forgive me if I get a ticket for trespassing.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The cop nods at that, seeming to have a fair grasp of marital dynamics. He flashes a smile but suddenly stops, whips out his gun and trains it on her --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holy shit. (clicks the safety off)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lady, stay right where you are. Miranda shuts her eyes, busted.     Freezes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hands up where I can see them. Miranda awkwardly raises her shaky hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice and slow, start talking to me. And make it good. Tell me just exactly who that is. A confused Miranda slowly turns in the direction he's looking to see Tracy Seaver at the barn door. Dragging herself in agony, clearly in a severe state of shock. Battered, yet somehow -- incredibly -- still alive. But just barely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A car pulls up to the chaotic ER area.       Phil Parsons Pete step out, rush inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sheriff Ryan is busy at the urinal. But even here he can't find any peace because Teddy Howard is on his case --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Howard -- let me simply list the events your client was involved in last night. First she drugs a janitor, steals his car and escapes a mental institution --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold on, there isn't even any substantial evidence --

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Sheriff Ryan zips up his pants, flushes and runs the sink to wash his hands --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Howard -- there isn't evidence because the overdosed janitor hasn't woken up, that's why -- and when your client was questioned on the matter she admitted to injecting a full syringe of --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (handing him a paper towel)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You had no right to question my client without my presence --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Howard, this is not a courtroom. Your client was read her rights and she still insisted --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Let me ask you this, Sheriff: what exactly was a janitor doing with several vials of sedatives inside my client's cell? And is it not possible he had taken some drugs himself before my client -- Sheriff Ryan discards the paper towel and walks out to the waiting room, Teddy following closely --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paramedics and nurses doing their thing. The young officer who arrested Miranda hands the Sheriff a cup of coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not a drug expert. I'm simply stating the frigging facts. Sheriff Ryan burns his tongue on the coffee, notices Parsons and Pete approaching. Relief crosses his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil, thank God -- this guy's driving me nuts!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An 'incident' -- for lack of a better frigging word -- involving Miss Grey and a teenage girl who's been tortured and is in critical condition and chances are slim she'll even utter another word.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's the girl?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A runaway from Portland, Tracy Marie Seaver. Reported missing a couple weeks ago. We found Miss Grey in some barn off Willows Creek with the girl all messed up. I'm just now waiting for the surgeon to give me an update. (to Teddy)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Notice, Counselor, how I'm not even mentioning her trespassing or lying to a police officer. Teddy waves him off in frustration.     Goes to talk to Turlington.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christ, the woman's got the entire hospital busy -- Sheriff Ryan notices Teddy talking to Turlington --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why are you harassing my deputies?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm only asking him where he got the coffee -- ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's not at liberty to answer that. You've had enough goddamn coffee already. The Sheriff leaves Pete and Parsons. They walk over to the water cooler where they can talk more privately.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We need to get Miranda back to the institute. She needs psychiatric care, not a prison cell.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Parsons nods, lost in thought.        Sheriff Ryan return

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil, how well does your wife know the suspect?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do you ask?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because she's at the station right now, demanding to speak with her. Parsons frowns at this, concerned.        Pete studies hi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bare room. A desk and two chairs. Glass window         pa insure no privacy. DOROTHY PARSONS (50s) waits,        se The door opens and a DEPUTY escorts Miranda in.        Sh across from Dorothy, looking as lost as can be.        A beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How are you? Miranda doesn't answer. Her mind elsewhere.         Namel at the barn and how it connects to Rachel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I needed to see you, but I'm not sure where to begin. I don't know you well, I certainly have nothing but fond feelings for you. Phil always keeps me posted on his colleagues and his work and -- in any case, I have always thought of you as a very bright, very perceptive doctor. Even though I don't know you well. She pauses here. Miranda looks up now. Her face hollow and exhausted. Bags under her eyes. A person who has seen too much. Wondering where the hell this is going.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My point is, my point being -- when Rachel died I had, um, I suffered through these spells, these recurring dreams.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And eventually, once I came to terms with her death, they went away. Losing a child is the hardest, most inconceivable event a mother can -- She drifts off.     Takes a beat to collect herself and resume:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The past few days I have been having the same dream. A nightmare. Miranda can't help but smile to herself at that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That word.   Nightmare.   Welcome to my life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This nightmare involves Rachel but it also involves you. In the nightmare Rachel holds a box in her left hand. A small box. And she repeats a series of numbers. Now, Rachel never spoke, from the time she was born -- she had a condition -- I often asked God why he punished this child in such a way -- she couldn't speak, but she was extremely bright. She wasn't autistic as the doctors claimed -- Dorothy Parsons starts to cry. A moment passes like this. It seems she won't recover enough to continue her tale.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Parsons, you need a therapist. Normally I would encourage you to schedule a session with me but as you can see -- Dorothy shakes her head, determined to finish.       She out a folded piece of paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every night the same box in her hand and the same numbers. I wrote them down.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She slides the paper over. Miranda watches her carefully, then looks at the piece of paper. The numbers are: 1-0-2-2-0-1. A long beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a message. It's a code for something. I don't know what. But she wants you to have it. Miranda studies it. Studies this woman, who quite frankly seems to have completely lost her mind. Then she looks back at the numbers and is slowly hit with a realization.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: October 22nd, 2001. It's my wedding date. She stares at Dorothy, stunned. Brain click-click- clicking. Her wildest fears confirmed: Doug is behind this somehow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That code belongs to a safety deposit box my husband kept in a bank up in Newcastle, that's where his parents live. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dorothy, I need you to drive up there and open it. Dorothy stares at her, scared.     And finally nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete hurries down the front steps of the main building as TWO POLICE CRUISERS pull up. Miranda is brought out of one of the cruisers by two OFFICERS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can take those off now. Sheriff Ryan leans out of the other cruiser.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't push it, Doctor. She's cuffed until your people secure her in a cell.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Pete sighs, gestures for the officers to bring her in. Irene and two heavy-duty orderlies will also be part of the escort. Miranda locks eyes with Pete as she approaches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you alright?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was wrong. It wasn't Phil Parsons. It was Doug.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can we talk about this later? (to Sheriff)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, Sheriff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tomorrow morning first thing my deputies are here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know, I know. We'll see you then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And my offer still stands if you need added security.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. She won't go anywhere. I guarantee it. The Sheriff waves, whatever. Knocks twice on the hood and the officer behind the wheel shifts into drive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's why Rachel picked me.    It was Doug. I'm so stupid. Pete regards her now, has no idea what she's going on about this time. Tries to remain professional.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inside, okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lunch time for the female wing. An excited Shelley rushes over to a table where Chloe and Jenna are, whispers something to them. They glance at the door.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: A moment later, Miranda walks in with her police escort. Taking her across the cafeteria towards the back door. An uneasy Pete leads. Irene and the wardens at the rear. Miranda glances at the women staring at her like a specimen. Like somehow she's even more dangerous than them. Top dog, as it were, of the crazies. And then, halfway across the room, one of the women stands up. Chloe. She claps her hands together. Slowly. Miranda watches her, confused. And slowly Shelly, Jenna and others rise as well. All of them joining Chloe in clapping.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's a hero. Little Red Riding Hood put the big bad wolf in a coma. Pete nods.     Just what he needed.   The OFFICERS trade

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're not gonna start something, are they? Irene shakes her head, amused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ain't scared of a bunch of women now, are you, Officer? The entire cafeteria is on their feet showing their solidarity for Miranda. Chloe locks eyes with her, mouths the words "thank you." And Miranda is hauled out the side door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: White. Surveillance cameras in every corner. Two separate doors with elaborate locks. High security all around. The officers undo Miranda's cuffs and excuse themselves. Pete gestures for Irene and the Orderlies to leave as well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll be right outside, Doctor.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Once the doors are locked and they're alone, the conversation jumps straight into frustrated high gear:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I pulled a lot of strings to get you transferred back. The best case scenario you're looking at right now is five years here. Five. Under my --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter, I didn't believe in ghosts before this. And neither do you. Pete is at the end of his rope. Can't hide his sadness when he looks at her. Still, he tries to get her back on track:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you know that the brain is fully capable of tricking you into seeing all sorts of things. The simplest chemical deficiencies can --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chemical deficiencies can't get inside of you and make you do terrible things you don't remember doing!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a very open-minded person, but as a doctor --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, you're not. You're a close- minded academic, just like me. You told me once that I was the most logical person you knew, remember? Well, everything that's happened has an explanation but it has nothing to do with psychiatry or science. Rachel Parsons was abducted and she was murdered six years ago -- tossed off the Ashley Bridge by my husband. My harmless, righteous 'community leader' husband -- that's how pathetically blind I've been.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andrea White and Jenny Dixon were also abducted and murdered -- now this was before I met Doug but I bet you anything that they both went to his school. Then he obviously stopped for a while: fear, guilt, distractions -- namely me -- delayed him from reverting to his sickness. That's why I didn't notice anything. I believe he really tried to lead a normal life, for me. Then along comes Tracy Seaver and he can't resist. Locks her up and tortures her in some abandoned property -- She shows him the crumpled newspaper listing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here's Doug's interest in real estate, Pete. Pete stares at the realty listing for Willows Creek.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rachel Parsons is a pissed-off ghost with an agenda, furious at her parents for giving up on her -- she's been trying to communicate with them for years but they're too goddamn logical to pay attention -- and she picked me, she sought me out that night and sent me home to fix her problem. Made sure I killed Doug because he was going to do the same thing to Tracy Seaver as he did to her. And she will get rid of anyone who stands in her way. Pete takes all of this in.     Dumbfounded.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that a threat?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To whom?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To you? I'm telling you she nearly electrocuted me when I tried to leave town and she led me to that barn and if I don't do what she wants -- she's going to kill me. Pete can see that she's petrified. He starts to speak, but she hushes him by gently placing her finger on his lips. The gesture is tender, almost romantic. A reminder of their very real connection.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need you to at least consider the possibility that I'm not insane. (beat; pleading)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not as a doctor. As the only person I trust in this world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A tense Phil and Dorothy Parsons in their parked car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not doing it for Miranda, I'm doing this for Rachel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're making a complete fool of yourself. Do you realize what you sound like? She sighs, climbs out of the car, leaving him there. Takes three steps. Stops. Turns back around and lets him have it:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do I sound like, Phil? Like one of your patients? Well, it's probably because that's exactly how you treat me. And I've had enough of this deafening silence between us, this exemplary mourning in front of the community, tiptoeing around our lives with you pretending Rachel never existed. BANK CUSTOMERS walk around the argument, pretending not to hear. Phil is mortified. But Dorothy doesn't care:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm losing my mind. Our daughter is gone and I miss her and I'm angry. She turns and storms off. Phil takes it all in for the first time. A moment later he climbs out of the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A solemn GUARD places the safety deposit box on the table in the middle of the room. Steps back through the gate and waits. Dorothy and Phil stare at the box for a moment. Finally, Phil punches in the code written out by his wife and opens it. He sorts through some paperwork that means nothing to him until his hands feel a thick envelope. He opens it and spills the contents on the table. It is a stack of POLAROIDS. Dorothy leans in and immediately her face darkens. She grabs onto the table, shakily -- and is forced to sit down. A horrified sob rises from deep inside her, comes out like the howl of a dying animal. Her husband pales, all blood draining from his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sky darkens fast.     The storm moving in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THUNDER RUMBLES outside, making a tray of meds rattle. PAN UP to see Consuelo, the round black woman we might remember Chloe beating up earlier. She shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's gonna be an interesting night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miranda looks up at the sound of the BOLT BEING DRAWN and the handle unfastened. Through the door comes Consuelo, carrying a tray. Sets it down by the bed. She is on her way out when she pauses, stares at Miranda.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How are we doing today? That term again, "we." Doctor-speak.         Miranda does have the energy for it:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just fine, thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The spirit is not fine.    She's very unhappy. What was that? Normally Miranda would look at this woman as if she were crazy, but things have changed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How -- how do you know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shuts her eyes)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But she's only a girl. Do you know her name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.   Rachel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you talked to her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I -- you could say that. Consuelo holds Miranda's hands firmly, "reading" her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's very, very angry. And she's not finished with you yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure that's meant to sound comforting but --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She wants to show you something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That may be so, but I want her to go away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then you need to protect yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And how exactly would I do that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mira, first I'm gonna bring you some cascarilla, it's a powder, you get it anyplace, it comes from eggs -- you pour it all over you -- (indicates)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like this --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look -- (reading nametag)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Consuelo, I appreciate what you're trying to do, but I honestly don't think this ghost will go away if I pour some egg powder on myself -- Consuelo holds up a finger, hushing Miranda.      She's receiving something here. Shudders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She made you do things.   Bad things, didn't she?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you carried this out for her. She used you as a vessel... Consuelo's grip tightens on Miranda as we --

dialogues.speaker: FLASHBACK
dialogues.text: We're back at the bridge.     Rachel pries open Miranda's mouth. Miranda panics:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing? I'm trying to help you -- ?! Rachel opens her mouth wide like a snake. And as Miranda screams, blood starts leaking out of Rachel's wounds. And now we see it. Rachel's lips touch Miranda's and BREATHE HER SPIRIT INTO Miranda with a WHOOSH --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Consuelo lets go of Miranda's hand. Like recoiling from fire. Speaks in the simplest of ways. The truth: CONSUELO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were possessed by her. MIRANDA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. CONSUELO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ay, probrecita. You're both in terrible danger. She's scared too but she can't step back into the light until she finishes what she started here. And now you're the only person who can help her find the way back. MIRANDA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know how to do that -- I'm not qualified for it. You do it. Consuelo crosses herself. A sign of respect for the situation. But it has a chilling effect on Miranda. CONSUELO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Despair is the only unforgivable sin. You'll be in my prayers, Miranda. Prayers?   What good is that going to do?   Consuelo exit

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two POLICE CRUISERS parked outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A glassy-eyed Phil Parsons serves himself another Scotch, devastated. The SHOT is FRAMED so that we see the bedroom door is open, Dorothy lying in bed, heavily tranquilized. Sheriff Ryan inspects the photographs.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE LURID POLAROIDS
dialogues.text: Postcards from hell: scared teenage girls in forced poses -- gagged, tortured -- Andrea White, Jenny Dixon, Tracy Seaver...

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: And young Rachel Parsons.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This proves that her story is true: my daughter appeared to her in some form and guided her through all this, putting things right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Phil, you of all people --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I of all people hold logic, reason and facts above everything else. And seek the truth through proof and proof only. (re: pictures)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what do you call that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Has it occurred to you that maybe she knew what her husband was doing to those girls?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.   Frankly, it hasn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe she couldn't stand the guilt and cooked up this far-fetched tale to tug at everybody's heartstrings. The fact remains she hacked her husband to pieces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The fact remains my daughter was murdered and Miranda stopped the killer. A killer who was loose under your incompetent nose for over six years. We don't know how many future victims were spared, but we do know she saved that girl in the barn's life. And that's more than you or I can say -- !

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Calm down. For the record, that girl is on a ventilator. The doctors don't think she'll make it through tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, you want to stand up in a courtroom and tell a judge that a ghost is behind all this, that's your prerogative -- but I have to abide by the law. And the law says Miranda Grey faces criminal chargers. So here's what we're going to do. I'm going to leave a cruiser outside to make sure you don't go anywhere tonight and two of my deputies will go guard Ms. Grey until tomorrow morning. Phil? Parsons doesn't respond.     His eyes far away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There will be no breakouts, no aiding and abetting, no taking the law into your own hands. It'll take an Act of God for Miranda Grey not to show up in that courtroom tomorrow. Are we clear? And now the Sheriff can see that Parsons is crying. Quietly, miserably. And it's a disparaging sight. Sheriff Ryan exits. Two deputies follow, RADIOS SQUAWKING. Parsons remains still for a moment, then digs a photograph out of a drawer. A picture of Rachel in happier times.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. I will never forgive myself for what happened to you. Not as long as I live. (breaking down)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I miss you so much. He sits there, staring at his dead daughter. Grieving. WE PULL BACK to see he is not alone. Rachel is watching him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The WIND has really PICKED UP now. A massive LIGHTNING BOLT streaks the sky, officially announcing the storm's onset. A POLICE CRUISER pulls up to the guard gate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PAN OFF the bank of monitors TO the same two guards we've seen before. Playing yet another bored card game. The LIGHT RAPPING on their glass door makes them look up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Help you? TWO OFFICERS stand there.       We recognize one of them:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're here on Miranda Grey detail. The Guards shake their heads, chuckle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sixth floor. You can get a couple chairs from the nurses up there. A pretty decent cup of joe too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, guys. The Guard points at the bank of monitors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Although why the Sheriff is making you fellas waste your time is beside me. We got her right here. She ain't going no place.

dialogues.speaker: ON MONITOR
dialogues.text: Miranda inside her pristine white cell.       Restlessly pacing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks perfectly harmless, doesn't she?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't they all, Officer, don't they all? The men share a chuckle over that one when suddenly THUNDER CRACKLES and the power goes out. No monitors, no radio, no nothing.       Pitch black.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit.   There goes the card game. Abruptly there's a SERIES OF sharp CLICKS as FOUR FLASHLIGHTS come alive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The THUNDER outside RATTLES the WINDOW PANE. The only light source being the intermittent LIGHTNING as the STORM RAGES. She paces in the dark.    Sits.   Waits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two cops use their flashlights to hustle up the stair

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miranda holds her breath, listens. And sure enough, somebody else is in the room. She looks around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.   No.   What do you want -- ? And now LIGHTNING streaks the room and we see Rachel in the corner. Staring with her dead eyes. Moving towards her. MIRANDA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've done everything you've asked me to. My life is ruined. I can't take this anymore. I can't... (faintly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have to step into the light, Rachel. You don't belong here -- you don't belong... But it doesn't work. Rachel keeps walking towards her. Miranda backs up against the wall. Trapped. Fighting tears -- MIRANDA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Into the light -- (loudly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can somebody come in here?       I need help. Somebody, please!

dialogues.speaker: SAME TIME
dialogues.text: The cops reach the landing where we see other flashlights down the corridor. They walk towards them. IRENE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And who are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Officer Turlington, ma'am. We're supposed to sit outside Miranda Grey's cell all night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Knock yourself out. Next floor up. (loudly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's only a power outage, ladies -- let's call it an early night. The cops head down the corridor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rachel stretches out her arm to Miranda's face --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please don't. Why are you doing this? It's over. Over and done! Rachel slowly shakes her head, places her hands on Miranda's eyes and shuts them --

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA'S VISION
dialogues.text: in her school uniform. Staring straight ahead. Now the image is bathed in a red and blue light and we see her half-naked, bruised. Dead.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY DIXON
dialogues.text: staring AT us in her school uniform. Now abruptly she is a hellish vision: opening her mouth in agony, also bathed in the strange red and blue light -- END OF MIRANDA'S VISION.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miranda screams at the visions.    Rachel holds her stead

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop it! I don't want to see this! I can't help you anymore! Stop it!

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Now a heavy RATTLING makes her turn to the door. One of the HINGES has SHATTERED and the latch itself is half- pulled from the doorframe. Relentless POUNDING on the other side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me out of here! Let me out! There's a deafening SOUND like a thousand bells ringing at once and Miranda covers her ears -- Outside WE HEAR MURMURS, YELLS, INSTRUCTIONS --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cops arrive to find every door in the corridor flung open. Confused patients spill out as guards and nurses try to restore order. RADIOS SQUAWK, flashlights beam and FOOTSTEPS fill the dark corridor as patients try to escape.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: FIRE ENGINES and PATROL CARS arrive at the scene, SIRENS blazing. Sheriff Ryan and additional deputies rush from their cars to contain the breakout. A large SPOTLIGHT comes to life. We spot Jenna making a run for the garden wall when the spotlight hits her. Two officers rush after her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sheriff Ryan makes his way through the mayhem, past Irene helping a patient, past nurse Claire cowering in a corner

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christ Almighty. Sheriff Ryan hits the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Officer Turlington runs down the corridor, searching frantically with his flashlight --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A car pulls up at the scene.     Pete and Parsons step ou

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miranda... Pete rushes up the steps --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Officer Turlington looks inside Miranda's cell. Empty. And as he is about to speak into his walkie he spots her: Seated by the elevator. Holding a biting block in Shelley's mouth as her seizing subsides.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into radio)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sheriff? I have Miss Grey right here. He flashes his light at her.     Miranda looks back blank

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, we thought you might have made a run for it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Page Irene ASAP. This patient needs her meds. Turlington nods. Miranda looks down at a grateful Shelley, whose head is cradled in her lap. Brushes the matted hair off her face. Carefully removes the biting block, making sure Shelley is alright.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're gonna get that Pulitzer after all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shh, shh, just rest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sotto, smiling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you I could keep a secret.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The patients are all assembled here. Flashlights galore. Irene and Consuelo do head counts. Guards, officers, janitors -- everybody. Irene points a finger at Jenna.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have really disappointed me tonight, Jenna --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give me a break. You wouldn't respect me if I hadn't tried -- Parsons breaks away from Turlington, heads over to Pete and Miranda --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everybody accounted for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're doing the final count.   Now they can't find the Sheriff. Miranda scans the near-dark room, looking for someone. Watches Turlington step aside to take a call on his radio.   Parsons regards her with newfound respect:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you alright, Miranda?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine, Phil.   Thanks for asking. Suddenly all the policemen in the room begin to exit --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's going on, Officer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of your patients is holding the Sheriff at gunpoint. She's in the cafeteria. Pete glances at Miranda.      She knows exactly who it is

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chloe. Turlington is about to exit when Parsons stops him:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think Doctor Grey should be the one to talk to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The DOOR CRASHES open and Chloe shoves the Sheriff inside. She has a gun pressed hard against his ear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Young lady, I don't know how you think you can get out of here, but --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're very polite for a piggy. Now take off your uniform. Sheriff Ryan hesitates.      Chloe presses the gun agains him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do it quick.   I won't make fun of you. The sound of the UPSTAIRS DOOR BEING THROWN OPEN makes her glance up. She trains her flashlight at the second level, stepping behind the Sheriff to use him as cover.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody better fucking move up there or I'll blow this piggy's head off! Her FLASHLIGHT BEAM searches the section. Catches the reflection of a police shield hiding behind a table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That means you, fucko. Up on your feet or I'll start by shooting his ear off. A beat.   Officer Turlington rises.      Slow and deliber

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Sheriff, sotto)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell junior the grownups are talking now and he's not allowed in here. Do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Turlington, it's alright. I can -- I'm just going to --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The grownups are talking.   Don't paraphrase me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The grownups are -- are talking now. Just leave.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: A voice startles Chloe from behind, at floor level.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chloe?   Can I talk to you? Chloe flicks the flashlight to see Miranda by the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dreadful timing, I'm real busy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have to let him go.   I'm sorry. Chloe flinches at that. Like all this multitasking is affecting her. She digs the gun deeper into the Sheriff's neck, making him cower to his knees, execution style --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look -- let's not confuse things. I like you. But this is my only chance. (to Sheriff)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now take off that goddamn uniform before I get really pissed. The Sheriff glances at Miranda. Miranda nods.       The Sheriff begins unbuttoning his shirt --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you going to do? Put on his uniform and walk out of here? Think about it, Chloe. They know you have him. The place is crawling with cops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are my options? To grow old in this place? It's clear they will never let me go. Never. Ever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not true. You have less than a year left here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a lie! I'll never stop being sick, they'll just find something new that's wrong with me. No wonder you doctors can't help anyone -- all you have are deficit columns and stupid tests designed to point out what part of the puzzle you think we're missing!

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She starts sobbing.     Letting everything go --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're right, doctors never concentrate on the things patients are actually capable of. But I know you, Chloe, you've been through things that most people don't survive. And you have a wonderful future in front of you if you choose it. It's up to you. This gets through to Chloe.       Her grip loosens on the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No more guilt, no more hatred, no more unbearable sadness. You have no use for any of that anymore. Your life begins this very second.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm so tired.    So goddamn tired -- Miranda walks over and embraces her.       Chloe hands he gun. And that's when the power returns. Miranda and Chloe frozen in their embrace. Sheriff Ryan on his knees. In the sudden, shocking glare of returning light, color abruptly re-enters the world and every RADIO, PHONE, FAN and MACHINE that were left on HUM TO LIFE. Miranda finds herself staring at Sheriff Ryan, bathed in the glow of the flashing red and blue lights from the cruisers outside. The image a replica of the Andrea White and Jenny Dixon visions. Peeking from his half-unbuttoned shirt is the beginning of a chest TATTOO. Miranda slowly trains the gun on the Sheriff, finally struck with the realization:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was you, wasn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you talking about? She opens his shirt to reveal the tattoo: a 1950s pinup- style WOMAN SURROUNDED BY FLAMES, ARMS RAISED, SHACKLED. Anima Sola. Miranda's recurring vision from the night of the slaughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Not alone.' That's what Rachel has been trying to tell me all along. Doug was not alone. You were with him. This whole time it's been you. You covered up their deaths to look like suicides. The Sheriff throws his jacket on, starts walking --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've lost your mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't fucking move. The CLICK! of a SAFETY being released makes him pause. He turns to look at her. A tense beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miranda, don't do it! She glances at Pete's pleading face and the room around her: cops everywhere. All guns trained on her. Sheriff Ryan speaks low so only she can hear the following:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And just exactly who would believe you? No proof, no living witness. Everybody knows you're crazy. Miranda's finger itches on the trigger as they face off. Her hand starts to shake. Sheriff Ryan turns and strides off. Getting away. Further. Further... But as much as she wants to, she can't bring herself to do it. Finally brings the gun down. The armed policemen rush over and disarm her, shove her to the floor and cuff her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want that woman in custody. She has a judge to face in the morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Turlington escorts a cuffed Miranda to a waiting cruiser. He jumps behind the wheel and starts to pull out when Pete suddenly taps on Miranda's window, startling her --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll call your lawyer and -- !

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir, not now --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll meet you at the station! She shakes her head.     Mouths something Pete can't make

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir, please --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? Turlington hits the gas. Miranda presses her face against the window so only Pete can see her say the following:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The girl in the hospital. Pete locks eyes with her, nods -- as the cruiser leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tracy Seaver lies unconscious, hooked up to a series of machines. PULL BACK to find Pete with a young DOCTOR.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her condition remains the same. Basically that ventilator is keeping her alive. We have no reason to think she'll ever wake up. I'm sorry. Pete nods, disconcerted.      Stares at the girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mind if I stay here tonight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, it's a big place. The more the merrier. If I can just ask you to wait outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Doctor gestures for Pete to make himself comfortable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Brooks to ER. Dr. Brooks --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's me.   Excuse me. The Doctor rushes off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like Tracy Seaver, Simon Reynolds is hooked up to a bunch of machines and cables. Suddenly his EYES SHOOT OPEN and the CARDIAC ALARM SQUEALS -- Two NURSES rush in.       The young Doctor right behind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: V-tach. The EKG whipsaws. The Doctor feels for a pulse, then slap on the defibrillator pads, places the paddles on the ches

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clear! He begins chest compressions on Simon's heart. He spasms violently once, twice -- And then it stops. The Doctor and Nurses stare at the monitor. Flatline. Unseen by them, Rachel steps out of the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WE SEE Turlington and two other COPS climb in a patrol car and drive off. WE MOVE INSIDE the empty station...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sheriff Ryan takes a healthy chug from a fifth of Scotch, slips it back in a drawer. Stares at his hands. Steady as a rock. Takes a deep breath. Knows what he must do next. A religious man despite everything, he brings his thumb to his forehead and crosses himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miranda's eyes snap open at the SOUND OF DEADBOLTS SLIDING UNLOCKED. Hopeful. Could this be Rachel?

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: A looming figure appears at the door. Doesn't bother to shut it. Stares at her silently for a long while. And so begins a claustrophobic cat and mouse game:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How did you know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You tell me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This isn't one of your word association games, Doctor. Did Douglas tell you that night?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why wait this long if he had?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe it's your amnesia. Maybe you blocked it out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe. But it seems to me that it's vital you know for sure. He studies her. Takes a step towards her. Miranda responds by stepping back. A slow motion semicircle, if you will. She eyes the open door. Tempted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think me and Doug are monsters. That this was all a carefully laid out plan with those girls. But it wasn't that at all. You do things sometimes and you're not sure why you did them. Then you realize you can live with them and so can everyone else. Life goes on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you're looking for forgiveness, you came to the wrong place. She's stalling, trying to keep him talking and he knows it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One thing about fear is it makes people say the dumbest things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be that as it may, you're afraid too -- because you know killing me won't solve your problems.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My only problem is you.
